question: If \(\int\left(e^{2 x}+2 e^{x}-e^{-x}-1\right) e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)} d x=g(x) e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)}+c\), where \(c\) is a constant of integeration, then \(g(0)\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (d) \(\int\left(e^{2 x}+2 e^{x}-e^{-x}-1\right) \cdot e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)} d x\)


\(I=\int\left(e^{2 x}+e^{x}-1\right) \cdot e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)} d x+\int\left(e^{x}-e^{-x}\right) e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)} d x\)

\(=\int e^{x}\left(e^{x}+1-e^{-x}\right) \cdot e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)} d x+e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)}\)

\(=\int\left(e^{x}-e^{-x}+1\right) e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}+x\right)} d x+e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)}\)

Let \(e^{x}+e^{-x}+x=t \Rightarrow\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}+1\right) d x=d t\)

\(=\int e^{t} d t+e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)}=e^{t}+e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)}+C\)

\(=e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}+x\right)}+e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)}+C\)

\(=\left(e^{x}+1\right) \cdot e^{\left(e^{x}+e^{-x}\right)}+C\)

So, \(g(x)=1+e^{x}\) and \(g(0)=2\)

question: If \(\int \frac{\cos \theta}{5+7 \sin \theta-2 \cos ^{2} \theta} d \theta=A \log _{e}|B(\theta)|+C\), where \(C\) is a constant of integration, then \(\frac{B(\theta)}{A}\) can be :
solution:
}
  \item (d) Let \(\sin \theta=t \Rightarrow \cos \theta d \theta=d t\)


\(\int \frac{\cos \theta}{5+7 \sin \theta-2 \cos ^{2} \theta} d \theta=\frac{d t}{5+7 t-2+2 t^{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{d t}{\left(t+\frac{7}{4}\right)^{2}-\left(\frac{5}{4}\right)^{2}}=\frac{1}{5} \ln \left|\frac{t+\frac{1}{2}}{t+3}\right|+C\)

\(=\frac{1}{5} \ln \left|\frac{2 t+1}{t+3}\right|+C=\frac{1}{5} \ln \left|\frac{2 \sin \theta+1}{\sin \theta+3}\right|+C\)

\(\therefore B(\theta)=\frac{2 \sin \theta+1}{2(\sin \theta+3)}\) and \(A=\frac{1}{5}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{B(\theta)}{A}=\frac{5(2 \sin \theta+1)}{(\sin \theta+3)}\)\\

question: The integral \(\int\left(\frac{x}{x \sin x+\cos x}\right)^{2} d x\) is equal to (where \(C\) is a constant of integration) :
solution:
\item (a) \(\int \frac{x^{2}}{(x \sin x+\cos x)^{2}} d x\)

\(\because \frac{d}{d x}(x \sin x+\cos x)=x \cos x\)

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_06_11_5bae6af2ed6dc69baf79g-126}
\end{center}

\(=\frac{x}{\cos x}\left[\frac{-1}{x \sin x+\cos x}\right]\)

\[
-\int \frac{x \sin x+\cos x}{\cos ^{2} x}\left[\frac{-1}{x \sin x+\cos x}\right] d x
\]

\(=\frac{x}{\cos x}\left[\frac{-1}{x \sin x+\cos x}\right]+\int \sec ^{2} x d x\)

\(=\frac{-x \sec x}{x \sin x+\cos x}+\tan x+C\)

question: Let \(f(x)=\int \frac{\sqrt{x}}{(1+x)^{2}} d x(x \geq 0)\). Then \(f(3)-f(1)\) is equal to :
solution: (d) \(\int \frac{\sqrt{x}}{(1+x)^{2}} d x (x>0)\)\ Put \(x=\tan ^{2} \theta \Rightarrow 2 x d x=2 \tan \theta \sec ^{2} \theta d \theta\)\ \(I=\int \frac{2 \tan ^{2} \theta \cdot \sec ^{2} \theta}{\sec ^{4} \theta} d \theta=\int 2 \sin ^{2} \theta d \theta\)\ \(=\theta-\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}+C\)\ \(\Rightarrow f(x)=\theta-\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{2 \tan \theta}{1+\tan ^{2} \theta}+C\)\ \(f(x)=\theta-\frac{\tan \theta}{1+\tan ^{2} \theta}+C=\tan ^{-1} \sqrt{x}-\frac{\sqrt{x}}{1+x}+C\)\ Now \(f(3)-f(1)=\tan ^{-1}(\sqrt{3})-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{1+3}-\tan ^{-1}(1)+\frac{1}{2}\)\ \[=\frac{\pi}{12}+\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\]

question: If \(\int \sin ^{-1}\left(\sqrt{\frac{x}{1+x}}\right) d x=A(x) \tan ^{-1}(\sqrt{x})+B(x)+C\), where \(C\) is a constant of integration, then the ordered pair \((A(x)\), \(B(x)\) ) can be :
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(I=\int \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{1+x}}\right) d x=\int \tan ^{-1} \sqrt{x} \cdot 1 d x\)\\
\(=x \tan ^{-1} \sqrt{x}-\int \frac{1}{1+x} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}} \cdot x d x+C\)\\
\(=x \tan ^{-1} \sqrt{x}-\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{t \cdot 2 t d t}{1+t^{2}}+C\)


(Put \(x=t^{2} \Rightarrow d x=2 t d t\) )

\(=x \tan ^{-1} \sqrt{x}-\int \frac{t^{2}}{1+t^{2}} d t+C\)

\(=x \tan ^{-1} \sqrt{x}-t+\tan ^{-1} t+C\)

\(=x \tan ^{-1} \sqrt{x}-\sqrt{x}+\tan ^{-1} \sqrt{x}+C\)

\(=(x+1) \tan ^{-1} \sqrt{x}-\sqrt{x}+C\)

\(\Rightarrow A(x)=x+1 \Rightarrow B(x)=-\sqrt{x}\)

question: The integral \(\int \frac{d x}{(x+4)^{8 / 7}(x-3)^{6 / 7}}\) is equal to: (where \(\mathrm{C}\) is a constant of integration)
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(\quad I=\int \frac{d x}{(x+4)^{8 / 7}(x-3)^{6 / 7}}\)


\(=\int\left(\frac{x-3}{x+4}\right)^{\frac{-6}{7}} \frac{1}{(x+4)^{2}} d x\)

Let \(\frac{x-3}{x+4}=t^{7}\),

Differentiate on both sides, we get

\(\frac{7}{(x+4)^{2}} d x=7 t^{6} d t\)

Hence, \(I=\int t^{-6} t^{6} d t=t+C=\left(\frac{x-3}{x+4}\right)^{\frac{1}{7}}+C\)

question: If \(\int \frac{d \theta}{\cos ^{2} \theta(\tan 2 \theta+\sec 2 \theta)}=\lambda \tan \theta+2 \log _{\mathrm{e}}|f(\theta)|+\) C where \(\mathrm{C}\) is a constant of integration, then the ordered pair \((\lambda, f(\theta))\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (c) \(I=\int \frac{d \theta}{\cos ^{2} \theta(\tan 2 \theta+\sec 2 \theta)}\)


\(=\int \frac{\sec ^{2} \theta}{\frac{1+\tan ^{2} \theta}{1-\tan ^{2} \theta}+\frac{2 \tan \theta}{1-\tan ^{2} \theta}} d \theta\)

\(=\int \frac{\sec ^{2} \theta\left(1-\tan ^{2} \theta\right)}{(1+\tan \theta)^{2}} d \theta\)

\(=\int \frac{\sec ^{2} \theta(1-\tan \theta)}{1+\tan \theta} d \theta\)

Let \(\tan \theta=t \Rightarrow \sec ^{2} \theta d \theta=d t\), then

\(I=\int\left(\frac{1-t}{1+t}\right) d t=\int\left(-1+\frac{2}{1+t}\right) d t\)

\(=-t+2 \log (1+t)+C\)

\(=-\tan \theta+2 \log (1+\tan \theta)+C\)

Hence, by comparison \(\lambda=-1\) and \(f(x)=1+\tan \theta\)\\

question: If \(\frac{\cos x d x}{\sin ^{3} x\left(1+\sin ^{6} x\right)^{2 / 3}}=f(x)\left(1+\sin ^{6} x\right)^{1 /}+c\) where \(c\) is a constant of integration, then \(\lambda f\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)\) is equal to:
solution:
\item (d) Let \(I=\int \frac{\cos x d x}{\sin ^{3} x\left(1+\sin ^{6} x\right)^{2 / 3}}\)

\(=f(x)\left(1+\sin ^{6} x\right)^{1 / \lambda}+\mathrm{c}\)

If \(\sin x=t\)

then, \(\cos x d x=d t\)

\(I=\int \frac{d t}{t^{3}\left(1+t^{6}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}}=\int \frac{d t}{t^{7}\left(1+\frac{1}{t^{6}}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}}\)

Put \(1+\frac{1}{t^{6}}=r^{3} \Rightarrow \frac{d t}{t^{7}}=\frac{-1}{2} r^{2} d r\)

\[
-\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{r^{2} d r}{r^{2}}=-\frac{1}{2} r+c
\]

\(=-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\sin ^{6} x+1}{\sin ^{6} x}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}+c=-\frac{1}{2 \sin ^{2} x}\left(1+\sin ^{6} x\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}+c\)

\(f(x)=-\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{cosec}^{2} x\) and \(\lambda=3\)

[from eqn. (i)]

\(\therefore \lambda f\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right)=-2\)

question: The integral \(\int \frac{2 x^{3}-1}{x^{4}+x} d x\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (c) Given integral, \(I=\int \frac{\left(2 x^{3}-1\right) d x}{x^{4}+x}=\int \frac{\left(2 x-x^{-2}\right) d x}{x^{2}+x^{-1}}\)


Put \(x^{2}+x^{-1}=u \Rightarrow\left(2 x-x^{-2}\right) d x=d u\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\int \frac{d u}{u}=\log |u|+c=\log \left|x^{2}+x^{-1}\right|+c\)

\(=\log \left|\frac{x^{3}+1}{x}\right|+c\)

question: Let \(\alpha \in(0, \pi / 2)\) be fixed. If the integral \(\int \frac{\tan x+\tan \alpha}{\tan x-\tan \alpha} d x=\mathrm{A}(x) \cos 2 \alpha+\mathrm{B}(x) \sin 2 \alpha+\mathrm{C}\), where \(\mathrm{C}\) is a constant of integration, then the functions \(\mathrm{A}(x)\) and \(\mathrm{B}(x)\) are respectively :
solution:
}
  \item (b) Given integral


\(\int \frac{\tan x+\tan \alpha}{\tan x-\tan \alpha} d x=\int \frac{\sin (x+\alpha)}{\sin (x-\alpha)} d x\)

Let \(x-\alpha=t \Rightarrow d x=d t\)

\(=\int \frac{\sin (t+2 \alpha)}{\sin t} d t=\int[\cos 2 \alpha+\sin 2 \alpha \cdot \cot t] d t\)

\(=\cos 2 \alpha \cdot t+\sin 2 \alpha \cdot \log |\sin t|+c\)

\(=(x-\alpha) \cdot \cos 2 \alpha+\sin 2 \alpha \cdot \log |\sin (x-\alpha)|+c\)

question: If \(\int \frac{d x}{\left(x^{2}-2 x+10\right)^{2}}\) \(=\mathrm{A}\left(\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{x-1}{3}\right)+\frac{f(x)}{x^{2}-2 x+10}\right)+\mathrm{C}\) where \(\mathrm{C}\) is a constant of integration, then :
solution:
}
  \item (a) Let \(I=\int \frac{d x}{\left(x^{2}-2 x+10\right)^{2}}=\int \frac{d x}{\left((x-1)^{2}+9\right)^{2}}\)


Let \((x-1)^{2}=9 \tan ^{2} \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow \tan \theta=\frac{x-1}{3}\)

After differentiating equation ...(i), we get

\(2(x-1) d x=18 \tan \theta \sec ^{2} \theta \mathrm{d} \theta\)

\(\therefore I=\int \frac{18 \tan \theta \sec ^{2} \theta d \theta}{2 \times 3 \tan \theta \times 81 \sec ^{4} \theta}\)

\(I=\frac{1}{27} \int \cos ^{2} \theta d \theta=\frac{1}{27} \times \frac{1}{2} \int(1+\cos 2 \theta) d \theta\)

\(I=\frac{1}{54}\left\{\theta+\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}\right\}+c\)

\(I=\frac{1}{54}\left[\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{x-1}{3}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{2\left(\frac{x-1}{3}\right)}{1+\left(\frac{x-1}{3}\right)^{2}}\right]+c\)

\(I=\frac{1}{54}\left[\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{x-1}{3}\right)+\frac{3(x-1)}{x^{2}-2 x+10}\right]+c\)

Compare it with \(\mathrm{A}\left[\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{x-1}{b}\right)+\frac{f(x)}{x^{2}-2 x+10}\right]+c\),

we get: \(\mathrm{A}=\frac{1}{54}\) and \(\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})=3(\mathrm{x}-1)\)

question: If \(f(x)\) is a non-zero polynomial of degree four, having local extreme points at \(x=-1,0,1\); then the set \(S=\{x \in R: f(x)=f(0)\}\) contains exactly:
options: two irrational and two rational numbers.
two irrational and one rational number.
solution:
}
  \item (d) Since, function \(f(x)\) have local extreem points at \(x=-1,0,1\). Then


\(f(x)=K(x+1) x(x-1)\)

\(=K\left(x^{3}-x\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})=K\left(\frac{x^{4}}{4}-\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right)+C\) (using integration)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{f}(0)=\mathrm{C}\)

\(\because \mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})=\mathrm{f}(0) \Rightarrow K\left(\frac{x^{4}}{4}-\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{x^{2}}{2}\left(\frac{x^{2}}{2}-1\right)=0 \quad \Rightarrow x=0,0, \sqrt{2},-\sqrt{2}\)

\(\therefore S=\{0,-\sqrt{2}, \sqrt{2}\}\)

question: The integral \(\int \sec ^{2 / 3} x \operatorname{cosec}^{4 / 3} x d x\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(I=\int \sec ^{\frac{2}{3}} x \cdot \operatorname{cosec}^{\frac{4}{3}} d x\)


\(I=\int \frac{\sec ^{2} x d x}{4}\)

\(\tan ^{3} x\)

Put \(\tan \mathrm{x}=\mathrm{z}\)

\(\Rightarrow \sec ^{2} \mathrm{xdx}=\mathrm{dz}\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\int z^{-\frac{4}{3}} \cdot d z=\frac{z^{\frac{-1}{3}}}{\left(\frac{-1}{3}\right)}+C \Rightarrow I=-3(\tan x)^{\frac{-1}{3}}+C\)\\

question: If \(\int e^{\sec x}\left(\sec x \tan x f(x)+\left(\sec x \tan x+\sec ^{2} x\right)\right) d x\) \(=e^{\sec x} f(x)+\mathrm{C}\), then a possible choice of \(f(x)\) is:
solution: (a) Given,\ \(\int e^{\sec x}\left(\sec x \tan x f(x)+\left(\sec x+\tan x+\sec ^{2} x\right)\right) d x\)\ \[=e^{\sec x} f(x)+C\] \(\because \int e^{g(x)}\left(\left(g^{\prime}(x) f(x)\right)+f^{\prime}(x)\right) d x=e^{g(x)} \times f(x)+C\)\ Our comparing above equation by equation (i),\ \(f(x)=\int\left((\sec x \tan x)+\sec ^{2} x\right) d x\)\ \(\therefore f(x)=\sec x+\tan x+C\)\\

question: \(\int \frac{\sin \frac{5 x}{2}}{\sin \frac{x}{2}} d x\) is equal to :
solution:
}
\item (c)


\[
\int \frac{\sin \left(\frac{5 x}{2}\right)}{\sin \left(\frac{x}{2}\right)} d x=\int \frac{2 \cos \frac{x}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{5 x}{2}}{2 \cos \frac{x}{2} \cdot \sin \frac{x}{2}} d x
\]

\(=\int \frac{\sin 3 x+\sin 2 x}{\sin x} d x\)

\(=\int\left(3-4 \sin ^{2} x+2 \cos x\right) d x\)

\(\left[\because \sin 2 x=2 \sin x \cos x\right.\) and \(\left.\sin 3 x=3 \sin x-4 \sin ^{3} x\right]\)

\(=\int(3-2(1-\cos 2 x)+2 \cos x) d x\)

\(=\int(1+2 \cos x+2 \cos 2 x) d x\)

\(=x+2 \sin x+\sin 2 x+c\)

question: If \(\int \frac{d x}{x^{3}\left(1+x^{6}\right)^{2 / 3}}=x f(x)\left(1+x^{6}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}+C\), where \(\mathrm{C}\) is a constant of integration, then the function \(f(x)\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (d) Let, \(\int \frac{d x}{x^{3}\left(1+x^{6}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}}=\int \frac{d x}{x^{7}\left(1+x^{-6}\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}}\)


Put \(1+x^{-6}=t^{3} \Rightarrow-6^{-7} d x=3 t^{2} d t \Rightarrow \frac{d x}{x^{7}}=\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right) t^{2} d t\)

Now, \(I=\int\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right) \frac{t^{2} d t}{t^{2}}=-\frac{1}{2} t+C\)

\(=-\frac{1}{2}\left(1+x^{-6}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}+C=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{\left(1+x^{6}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}}{x^{2}}+C\)

\(=-\frac{1}{2 x^{3}} x\left(1+x^{6}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}+C\)

Hence, \(f(x)=-\frac{1}{2 x^{3}}\)

question: The integral \(\int \cos \left(\log _{e} x\right) d x\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (c) Let the integral, \(I=\int \cos (\ln x) d x\)


\(\Rightarrow \quad I=\cos (\ln x) \cdot x-\int \frac{-\sin (\ln x)}{x} \cdot x d x\)

\(=x \cos (\ln x)+\int \sin (\ln x) d x\)

\(=x \cos (\ln x)+\sin (\ln x) \cdot x-\int \frac{\cos (\ln x)}{x} \cdot x d x\)

\(=x \cos (\ln x)+\sin (\ln x) \cdot x-I\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 I=x(\cos (\ln x)+\sin (\ln x))+C\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\frac{x}{2}[\cos (\ln x)+\sin (\ln x)]+C\)

question: The integral \(\int \frac{3 x^{13}+2 x^{11}}{\left(2 x^{4}+3 x^{2}+1\right)^{4}} d x\) is equal to:

If \(\int \frac{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}{x^{4}} d x=A(\mathrm{x})\left(\sqrt{1-x^{2}}\right)^{m}+C\), for a suitable chosen integer \(\mathrm{m}\) and a function \(\mathrm{A}(\mathrm{x})\), where \(\mathrm{C}\) is a constant of integration, then \((\mathrm{A}(\mathrm{x}))^{\mathrm{m}}\) equals :
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(A(x)\left(\sqrt{1-x^{2}}\right)^{m}+C=\int \frac{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}{x^{4}} d x\)


\(=\int \frac{\sqrt{\frac{1}{x^{2}}-1}}{x^{3}} d x\)

Let \(\frac{1}{x^{2}}-1=u^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow-\frac{2}{x^{3}}=\frac{2 u d u}{d x}\)

\(\frac{d x}{x^{3}}=-u d u\)

\(A(x)\left(\sqrt{1-x^{2}}\right)^{m}+C=\int\left(-u^{2}\right) d u=-\frac{u^{3}}{3}+C\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
& =-\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{1}{x^{2}}-1\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}+C \\
& =-\frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{x^{3}} \cdot\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}+C \\
& =\frac{-1}{3 x^{3}}\left(\sqrt{1-x^{2}}\right)^{3}+C
\end{aligned}
\]

Compare both sides,

\(\Rightarrow A(x)=-\frac{1}{3 x^{3}}\) and \(m=3\)

\(\Rightarrow(A(x))^{3}=\frac{-1}{27 x^{9}}\)

question: If \(\int \frac{x+1}{\sqrt{2 x-1}} \mathrm{~d} x=f(x) \sqrt{2 x-1}+\mathrm{C}\), where \(\mathrm{C}\) is a constant of integration, then \(f(x)\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (c) Let \(I=\int \frac{x+1}{\sqrt{2 x-1}} d x\)


Put \(\sqrt{2 x-1}=t\)

\(\therefore 2 x-1=t^{2} \Rightarrow d x=t d t\)

\(I=\int \frac{\left(t^{2}+3\right)}{2} d t=\frac{t^{3}}{6}+\frac{3 t}{2}+C\)

\(=\frac{(2 x-1)^{\frac{3}{2}}}{6}+\frac{3}{2}(2 x-1)^{\frac{1}{2}}+C\)

\(=\sqrt{2 x-1}\left(\frac{x+4}{3}\right)+C\)

\(=f(x) \cdot \sqrt{2 x-1}+C\)

Hence, \(f(x)=\frac{x+4}{3}\)

question: Let \(\mathrm{n} \geq 2\) be a natural number and \(0<\theta<\frac{\pi}{2}\) Then \(\int \frac{\left(\sin ^{\mathrm{n}} \theta+\sin \theta\right)^{\frac{1}{\mathrm{n}}} \cos \theta}{\sin ^{\mathrm{n}+1} \theta} \mathrm{d} \theta\) is equal to:
solution: (a) Let, \(I=\int \frac{\left(\sin ^{n} \theta-\sin \theta\right)^{\frac{1}{n}} \cos \theta}{\sin ^{n+1} \theta} d \theta\)\ \ Let \(\sin \theta=u\)\ \(\Rightarrow \cos \theta d \theta=d u\)\ \(\therefore \quad I=\int \frac{\left(u^{n}-u\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}}{u^{n+1}} d u\)\ \(=\int \frac{\left(1-\frac{1}{u^{n-1}}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}}}{u^{n}} d u=\int u^{-n}\left(1-u^{1-n}\right)^{\frac{1}{n}} d u\)\ \ Let \(1-u^{1-n}=v\)\ \(\Rightarrow-(1-n) u^{-n} d u=d v\)\ \(\Rightarrow u^{-n} d u=\frac{d v}{n-1}\)\ \(\therefore \quad I=\int v^{\frac{1}{n}} \cdot \frac{d v}{n-1}=\frac{1}{n-1} \cdot \frac{v^{\frac{1}{n}}}{\frac{1}{n}+1}\)\ \(=\frac{n}{n^{2}-1} v^{\frac{n+1}{n}}+C=\frac{n}{n^{2}-1}\left(1-\frac{1}{u^{n-1}}\right)^{\frac{n+1}{n}}+C\)\ \(=\frac{n}{n^{2}-1}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sin ^{n-1} \theta}\right)^{\frac{n+1}{n}}+C\)\\

question: For \(x^{2} \neq \mathrm{n} \pi+1, \mathrm{n} \in \mathrm{N}\) (the set of natural numbers), the integral \(\int x \sqrt{\frac{2 \sin \left(x^{2}-1\right)-\sin 2\left(x^{2}-1\right)}{2 \sin \left(x^{2}-1\right)+\sin 2\left(x^{2}-1\right)}} d x\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (c, d ) Consider the given integral


\(I=\int x \sqrt{\frac{2 \sin \left(x^{2}-1\right)-2 \sin \left(x^{2}-1\right) \cos \left(x^{2}-1\right)}{2 \sin \left(x^{2}-1\right)+2 \sin \left(x^{2}-1\right) \cos \left(x^{2}-1\right)}} d x\)

\((\therefore \sin 2 \theta=2 \sin \theta \cos \theta)\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\int x \sqrt{\frac{1-\cos \left(x^{2}-1\right)}{1+\cos \left(x^{2}-1\right)}} d x\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\int x\left|\tan \left(\frac{x^{2}-1}{2}\right)\right| d x\),

Now let \(\frac{x^{2}-1}{2}=t \Rightarrow \frac{2 x}{2} d x=d t\)

\(\therefore \quad I=\int|\tan (t)| d t=\ln |\sec t|+C\)

or \(\quad I=\ln \left|\sec \left(\frac{x^{2}-1}{2}\right)\right|+c=\frac{1}{2} \ln \left|\sec ^{2}\left(\frac{x^{2}-1}{2}\right)\right|+c\)

question: If \(f(x)=\int \frac{5 x^{8}+7 x^{6}}{\left(x^{2}+1+2 x^{7}\right)^{2}} d x,(x \geq 0)\), and \(f(0)=0\), then the value of \(f(1)\) is:
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(f(x)=\int \frac{5 x^{8}+7 x^{6}}{\left(x^{2}+1+2 x^{7}\right)^{2}} d x, x \geq 0\)


\(=\int \frac{5 x^{8}+7 x^{6}}{x^{14}\left(x^{-5}+x^{-7}+2\right)^{2}} d x\)

\(=\int \frac{5 x^{-6}+7 x^{-8}}{\left(2+x^{-7}+x^{-5}\right)^{2}} d x\)

Let \(2+x^{-7}+x^{-5}=t\)

\(\Rightarrow\left(-7 x^{-8}-5 x^{-6}\right) d x=d t\)

\(\Rightarrow f(x)=\int \frac{-d t}{t^{2}}=\int-t^{-2} d t=t^{-1}+c\)

\(\Rightarrow f(x)=\frac{1}{2+x^{-7}+x^{-5}}+c, f(0)=0 \Rightarrow c=0\)

\(\therefore f(1)=\frac{1}{4}\)\\

question: The integral \(\int \frac{\sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x}{\left(\sin ^{5} x+\cos ^{3} x \sin ^{2} x+\sin ^{3} x \cos ^{2} x+\cos ^{5} x\right)^{2}} d x\) is equal to:
solution:
\item (a) Let I

\[
\begin{aligned}
& =\int \frac{\sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x}{\left(\sin ^{5} x+\cos ^{3} x \sin ^{2} x+\sin ^{3} x \cos ^{2} x+\cos ^{5} x\right)^{2}} d x \\
& =\int \frac{\sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x}{\left[\left(\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x\right)\left(\sin ^{3} x+\cos ^{3} x\right)\right]^{2}} d x \\
& =\int \frac{\sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x}{\left(\sin ^{3} x+\cos ^{3} x\right)^{2}} d x=\int \frac{\tan ^{2} x \cdot \sec ^{2} x}{\left(1+\tan ^{3} x\right)^{2}} d x \\
& \Rightarrow 3 \tan ^{2} x \sec ^{2} x d x=d t \\
& \therefore \quad I=\frac{1}{3} \int \frac{d t}{t^{2}}=-\frac{1}{3 t}+C=\frac{-1}{3\left(1+\tan ^{3} x\right)}+C
\end{aligned}
\]

question: If \(\int \frac{\tan x}{1+\tan x+\tan ^{2} x} d x=x-\frac{K}{\sqrt{A}} \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{K \tan x+1}{\sqrt{A}}\right)+C\), ( \(C\) is a constant of integration), then the ordered pair \((K, A)\) is euqal to
solution:
}
  \item (a) Let \(I=\int \frac{\tan x}{1+\tan x+\tan ^{2} x} d x\)


\(\Rightarrow I=\int \frac{\tan x+1+\tan ^{2} x}{\tan x+1+\tan ^{2} x} d x-\int \frac{\left(1+\tan ^{2} x\right)}{1+\tan x+\tan ^{2} x}\)

\(\Rightarrow I=x-\int \frac{\sec ^{2} x d x}{1+\tan x+\tan ^{2} x}\)

Put \(\tan x=t \Rightarrow \sec ^{2} x . d x=d t\)

\(\therefore I=x-\int \frac{d t}{t^{2}+t+\frac{1}{4}+1-\frac{1}{4}}\)

\(=x-\int \frac{d t}{\left(t+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow I=x-\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{t+\frac{1}{2}}{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}}\right)+C\)

\(\Rightarrow I=x-\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2 \tan x+1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)+C\)

\(\therefore A=3\) and \(K=2\)

question: If \(f\left(\frac{x-4}{x+2}\right)=2 x+1,(x \in R=\{1,-2\})\), then \(\int f(x) d x\) is equal to (where \(C\) is a constant of integration)
solution:
}
  \item (b) Suppose, \(\frac{x-4}{x+2}=y \Rightarrow x-4=y(x+2)\)


\(\Rightarrow x(1-y)=2 y+4 \Rightarrow x=\frac{2 y+4}{1-y}\)

So, \(f(y)=2\left(\frac{2 y+4}{1-y}\right)+1\)

Now, \(f(x)=2\left(\frac{2 x+4}{1-x}\right)+1=\frac{3 x+9}{1-x}\)\\
\(=\frac{3(x+3)}{1-x}=\frac{3(\mathrm{x}-1+4)}{1-x}=-3+\frac{12}{1-x}\)

\(\therefore \int f(x) d x=-12 \log _{e}|1-x|-3 x+c\)

question: \(\int \frac{2 x+5}{\sqrt{7-6 x-x^{2}}} d x=A \sqrt{7-6 x-x^{2}}+B \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{x+3}{4}\right)+C\) (where \(C\) is a constant of integration), then the ordered pair \((A, B)\) is equal to
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(\because 7-6 x-x^{2}=16-(x+3)^{2}\)


and \(\frac{d}{d x}\left(7-6 x-x^{2}\right)=-2 x-6\)

So, \(\int \frac{2 x+5}{\sqrt{7-6 x-x^{2}}} d x=\int \frac{2 x+6}{\sqrt{7-6 x-x^{2}}} d x\)

\(-\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{16-(x+3)^{2}}} d x\)

\(=-2 \sqrt{7-6 x-x^{2}}-\sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{x+3}{4}\right)+C\)

Therefore, \(A=-2, \& B=-1\).

question: If \(f\left(\frac{3 x-4}{3 x+4}\right)=x+2, x \neq-\frac{4}{3}\), and \(\int f(x) d x=\mathrm{A} \log |1-x|+\mathrm{B} x+\mathrm{C}\), then the ordered pair \((\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B})\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (b) \(f\left(\frac{3 x-4}{3 x+4}\right)=x+2, x \neq-\frac{4}{3}\)


Consider \(\frac{3 \mathrm{x}-4}{3 \mathrm{x}+4}=\mathrm{t}\)

\(\Rightarrow 3 \mathrm{x}-4=3 \mathrm{tx}+4 \mathrm{t}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{x}=\frac{4 \mathrm{t}+4}{3-3 \mathrm{t}}+2\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{f}(\mathrm{t})=\frac{10-2 \mathrm{t}}{3-3 \mathrm{t}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})=\frac{2 \mathrm{x}-10}{3 \mathrm{x}-3}\)

\(\therefore \quad \int f(x) d x=\int \frac{2 x-10}{3 x-3} d x\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
& =\int \frac{2 x}{3 x-3} d x-10 \int \frac{d x}{3 x-3} \\
& =\frac{2}{3} \int \frac{\mathrm{x}-1}{\mathrm{x}-1} \mathrm{dx}+\frac{2}{3} \int \frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{x}-1}-\frac{10}{3} \int \frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{x}-1} \\
& =\frac{2 \mathrm{x}}{3}-\frac{8}{3} \ln (\mathrm{x}-1)+\mathrm{C}
\end{aligned}
\]

Here, \(\mathrm{A}=-\frac{8}{3}, \mathrm{~B}=\frac{2}{3}\)

\(\therefore \quad(\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B})=\left(-\frac{8}{3}, \frac{2}{3}\right)\)

question: The integral \(\int \sqrt{1+2 \cot x(\operatorname{cosec} x+\cot x)} d x\) \(\left(0<\mathrm{x}<\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (a) Let, \(I=\int \sqrt{1+2 \cot x \operatorname{cosec} x+2 \cot ^{2} x} \cdot d x\)


\[
\Rightarrow I=\int \sqrt{\frac{\sin ^{2} x+2 \cos x+2 \cos ^{2} x}{\sin ^{2} x}} \cdot d x
\]

\(\Rightarrow I=\int \sqrt{\frac{1+2 \cos x+\cos ^{2} x}{\sin x}} \cdot d x\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\int\left|\frac{1+\cos x}{\sin x}\right| \cdot d x\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\int|\operatorname{cosec} \mathrm{x}+\cot \mathrm{x}| \cdot \mathrm{dx}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}=\log |\operatorname{cosec} \mathrm{x}-\cot \mathrm{x}|+\log |\sin \mathrm{x}|+\mathrm{C}\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\log |1-\cos x|+C\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\log \left|2 \sin ^{2} \frac{x}{2}\right|+C\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\log \left|\sin ^{2} \frac{x}{2}\right|+\log 2+C\)

\(\Rightarrow I=2 \log \left|\sin \frac{x}{2}\right|+C_{1}\)

question: If \(\int \frac{d x}{\cos ^{3} \mathrm{x} \sqrt{2 \sin 2 \mathrm{x}}}=(\tan \mathrm{x})^{\mathrm{A}}+\mathrm{C}(\tan \mathrm{x})^{\mathrm{B}}+\mathrm{k}\), where \(\mathrm{k}\) is a constant of integration, then \(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B}+\mathrm{C}\) equals :

Let \(\tan x=t^{2} \Rightarrow \sec ^{2} x=1+t^{4}\)

\(\sec ^{2} x d x=2 t d t\)

\(=\int \frac{\sec ^{4} x d x}{2 \sqrt{\tan x}}=\int \frac{\sec ^{2} x\left(\sec ^{2} x d x\right)}{2 \sqrt{\tan x}}\)

\(=\int \frac{\left(1+t^{4}\right) 2 t d t}{2 t}=\int\left(1+t^{4}\right) d t=t+\frac{t^{5}}{5}+k\)

\(=\sqrt{\tan x}+\frac{1}{5} \tan ^{5 / 2} x+k[t=\sqrt{\tan x}]\)

\(A=\frac{1}{2}, B=\frac{5}{2}, C=\frac{1}{5}\)

\(A+B+C=\frac{16}{5}\)

question: If the integral \(\int \frac{\cos 8 x+1}{\cot 2 x-\tan 2 x} d x=A \cos 8 x+k\), where \(k\) is an arbitrary constant, then \(\mathrm{A}\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (a) Let \(\mathrm{I}=\int \frac{\cos 8 x+1}{\cot 2 x-\tan 2 x} d x\)


Now, \(\mathrm{D}^{r}=\cot 2 x-\tan 2 x=\frac{\cos 2 x}{\sin 2 x}-\frac{\sin 2 x}{\cos 2 x}\)

\(=\frac{\cos ^{2} 2 x-\sin ^{2} 2 x}{\sin 2 x \cos 2 x}=\frac{2 \cos 4 x}{\sin 4 x}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{I}=\int \frac{2 \cos ^{2} 4 x}{\frac{2 \cos 4 x}{\sin 4 x}} d x=\int \frac{2 \cos ^{2} 4 x \cdot \sin 4 x}{2 \cos 4 x} d x\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \int \sin 8 x d x=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{\cos 8 x}{8}+k=-\frac{1}{16} \cdot \cos 8 x+k\)

Now, \(-\frac{1}{16} \cdot \cos 8 x+k=\mathrm{A} \cos 8 x+k\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{A}=-\frac{1}{16}\)

question: If the \(\int \frac{5 \tan \mathrm{x}}{\tan \mathrm{x}-2} \mathrm{dx}=\mathrm{x}+\mathrm{a} \ln |\sin \mathrm{x}-2 \cos \mathrm{x}|+\mathrm{k}\), then \(a\) is equal to :
solution:
\item (d) \(\int \frac{5 \tan x}{\tan x-2} d x=\int \frac{5 \frac{\sin x}{\cos x}}{\frac{\sin x}{\cos x}-2} d x\)

\(=\int\left(\frac{5 \sin x}{\cos x} \times \frac{\cos x}{\sin x-2 \cos x}\right) d x\)

\(=\int \frac{5 \sin x d x}{\sin x-2 \cos x}\)

\(=\int\left(\frac{4 \sin x+\sin x+2 \cos x-2 \cos x}{\sin x-2 \cos x}\right) d x\)

\(=\int \frac{(\sin x-2 \cos x)+(4 \sin x+2 \cos x)}{\sin x-2 \cos x} d x\)

\(=\int \frac{(\sin x-2 \cos x)+2(\cos x+2 \sin x)}{(\sin x-2 \cos x)} d x\)

\(=\int \frac{\sin x-2 \cos x}{\sin x-2 \cos x} d x+2 \int\left(\frac{\cos x+2 \sin x}{\sin x-2 \cos x}\right) d x\)

\(=\int d x+2 \int \frac{\cos x+2 \sin x}{\sin x-2 \cos x} d x=I_{1}+I_{2}\)

where, \(I_{1}=\int d x\) and \(I_{2}=2 \int \frac{\cos x+2 \sin x}{\sin x-2 \cos x} d x\)

Let \(\sin x-2 \cos x=t\)

\(\Rightarrow(\cos x+2 \sin x) d x=d t\)

\(\therefore I_{2}=2 \int \frac{d t}{t}=2 \ln t+C=2 \ln (\sin x-2 \cos x)+C\)

Hence, \(I_{1}+I_{2}=\int d x+2 \ln (\sin x-2 \cos x)+c\)

\(=x+2 \ln |(\sin x-2 \cos x)|+k \Rightarrow a=2\)\\

question: If \(f(x)=\int\left(\frac{x^{2}+\sin ^{2} x}{1+x^{2}}\right) \sec ^{2} x d x\) and \(f(0)=0\), then \(f(1)\) equals
solution:
\item (a) Let \(f(x)=\int\left(\frac{x^{2}+\sin ^{2} x}{1+x^{2}}\right) \sec ^{2} x d x\)

\(=\int \frac{x^{2} \sec ^{2} x+\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{\cos ^{2} x}}{1+x^{2}} d x\)

\(=\int \frac{x^{2} \sec ^{2} x+\tan ^{2} x}{1+x^{2}} d x\)

\(=\int \frac{x^{2}\left(1+\tan ^{2} x\right)+\tan ^{2} x}{1+x^{2}} d x\)

\(=\int \frac{x^{2}+\tan ^{2} x\left(1+x^{2}\right)}{1+x^{2}} d x\)

\(=\int \frac{x^{2}}{1+x^{2}} d x+\int \tan ^{2} x d x\)

\(=\int \frac{x^{2}+1-1}{1+x^{2}} d x+\int\left(\sec ^{2} x-1\right) d x\)

\(=\int 1 d x-\int \frac{d x}{1+x^{2}}+\int \sec ^{2} x d x-\int d x\)

\(=-\tan ^{-1} x+\tan x+\mathrm{c}\)

Given : \(f(0)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow f(0)=-\tan ^{-1} 0+\tan 0+c \Rightarrow c=0\)

\(\therefore f(x)=-\tan ^{-1} x+\tan x\)

Now, \(f(1)=-\tan ^{-1}(1)+\tan 1=\tan 1-\frac{\pi}{4}\)

question: The integral of \(\frac{x^{2}-x}{x^{3}-x^{2}+x-1}\) w.r.t. \(x\) is
solution:
}
  \item (a) Let \(I=\int \frac{x^{2}-x}{x^{3}-x^{2}+x-1} d x\)


\(=\int \frac{x(x-1)}{x^{2}(x-1)+(x-1)} d x=\int \frac{x d x}{x^{2}+1}=\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{2 x d x}{\left(x^{2}+1\right)}\)

Let \(x^{2}+1=t \Rightarrow 2 x d x=d t\)

\(\therefore I=\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{d t}{t}=\frac{1}{2} \log t+c\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \log \left(x^{2}+1\right)+c\)

where ' \(c\) ' is the constant of integration.

question: Let \(f(x)\) be an indefinite integral of \(\cos ^{3} x\). Statement 1: \(f(x)\) is a periodic function of period \(\pi\). Statement 2: \(\cos ^{3} x\) is a periodic function.
options: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is false
Both the Statements are true, but Statement 2 is not the correct explanation of Statement 1.
Both the Statements are true, and Statement 2 is correct explanation of Statement 1.
Statement 1 is false, Statement 2 is true.
solution:
}
  \item (d) Statement \(-2: \cos ^{3} x\) is a periodic function.


It is a true statement.

Statement - 1

Given \(f(x)=\int \cos ^{3} x d x=\int\left(\frac{\cos 3 x}{4}+\frac{3 \cos x}{4}\right) d x\)

\(=\frac{1}{4} \frac{\sin 3 x}{3}+\frac{3}{4} \sin x=\frac{1}{12} \sin 3 x+\frac{3}{4} \sin x\)

Now, period of \(\frac{1}{12} \sin 3 x=\frac{2 \pi}{3}\)

Period of \(\frac{3}{4} \sin x=2 \pi\)

Hence period of \(f(x)=\frac{\text { L.C.M. }(2 \pi, 2 \pi)}{\text { HCF of }(1,3)}=\frac{2 \pi}{1}=2 \pi\)

Thus, \(f(x)\) is a periodic function of period \(2 \pi\).

Hence, Statement - 1 is false.

question: A value of \(\alpha\) such that \(\int_{\alpha}^{\alpha+1} \frac{d x}{(x+\alpha)(x+\alpha+1)}=\log _{e}\left(\frac{9}{8}\right)\) is :
solution:

\(=\int_{\alpha}^{\alpha+1}\left[\frac{1}{x+\alpha}-\frac{1}{x+\alpha+1}\right] d x\) [Using partial fraction]

\(=\left.\log \left(\frac{(x+\alpha)}{(x+\alpha+1)}\right)\right|_{\alpha} ^{\alpha+1}=\log \left(\frac{2 \alpha+1}{2 \alpha+2} \cdot \frac{2 \alpha+1}{2 \alpha}\right)\)

So, \(\frac{(2 \alpha+1)^{2}}{\alpha(\alpha+1)}=\frac{9}{2} \Rightarrow \quad 8 \alpha^{2}+8 \alpha+2=9 \alpha^{2}+9 \alpha\)

\(\Rightarrow \alpha^{2}+\alpha-2=0 \Rightarrow \alpha=1,-2\)

question: If \(\int x^{5} e^{-x^{2}} d x=g(x) e^{-x^{2}}+c\), where \(c\) is a constant of integration, then \(g(-1)\) is equal to :

question: If \(\int x^{5} \mathrm{e}^{-4 x^{3}} d x=\frac{1}{48} \mathrm{e}^{-4 x^{3}} f(x)+\mathrm{C}\), where \(\mathrm{C}\) is a constant of integration, then \(f(x)\) is equal to:

question: The integral \(\int \frac{d x}{(1+\sqrt{\mathrm{x}}) \sqrt{\mathrm{x}-\mathrm{x}^{2}}}\) is equal to : (where \(\mathrm{C}\) is a constant of integration)

}

Put \(1+\sqrt{x}=t \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}} d x=d t\)

\(\Rightarrow \quad 1=\int \frac{2 d t}{t \sqrt{2 t-t^{2}}}\)

Again put \(t=\frac{1}{z} \Rightarrow d t=\frac{-1}{2^{2}} d z\)

\(\Rightarrow I=2 \int \frac{\frac{-1}{z^{2}} d z}{\frac{1}{z} \sqrt{\frac{2}{z}-\frac{1}{z^{2}}}}=2 \int \frac{-d z}{\sqrt{2 z-1}}\)

\(=-2 \sqrt{\frac{2-t}{t}}+c=-2 \sqrt{\frac{1-\sqrt{x}}{1+\sqrt{x}}}+c\)

question: The integral \(\int \frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{x}^{2}\left(\mathrm{x}^{4}+1\right)^{3 / 4}}\) equals :

Let \(\mathrm{x}^{-4}=\mathrm{y}\)

\(\Rightarrow-4 \mathrm{x}^{-3} \mathrm{dx}=\mathrm{dy} \Rightarrow \mathrm{dx}=\frac{-1}{4} \mathrm{x}^{3} \mathrm{dy}\) \(\therefore \quad I=\frac{-1}{4} \int \frac{x^{3} d y}{x^{3}(1+y)^{3 / 4}}=\frac{-1}{4} \int \frac{d y}{(1+y)^{3 / 4}}\)

question: The integral \(\int \frac{\mathrm{dx}}{(\mathrm{x}+1)^{\frac{3}{4}}(\mathrm{x}-2)^{\frac{5}{4}}}\) is equal to :
If \(m\) is a non-zero number and \(\int \frac{x^{5 m-1}+2 x^{4 m-1}}{\left(x^{2 m}+x^{m}+1\right)^{3}} d x=f(x)+c\), then \(f(x)\) is:
solution:
}
  \item (b) \(\int \frac{x^{5 m-1}+2 x^{4 m-1}}{\left(x^{2 m}+x^{m}+1\right)^{3}} d x=\int \frac{x^{5 m-1}+2 x^{4 m-1}}{x^{6 m}\left(1+x^{-m}+x^{-2 m}\right)^{3}} d x\)


\(=\int \frac{x^{-m-1}+2 x^{-2 m-1}}{\left(1+x^{-m}+x^{-2 m}\right)^{3}} d x\)

Put \(t=1+x^{-m}+x^{-2 m}\)

\(\therefore \frac{d t}{d x}=-m x^{-m-1}-2 m x^{-2 m-1}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{d t}{-m}=\left(x^{-m-1}+2 x^{-2 m-1}\right) d x\)

\(\therefore \int \frac{x^{5 m-1}+2 x^{4 m-1}}{\left(x^{2 m}+x^{m}+1\right)^{3}} d x=\frac{1}{-m} \int t^{-3} d t=\frac{1}{2 m t^{2}}+C\)

\(=\frac{1}{2 m\left(1+x^{-m}+x^{-2 m}\right)^{2}}+C\)

\[
=\frac{x^{4 m}}{2 m\left(x^{2 m}+x^{m}+1\right)^{2}}+C
\]

\(\therefore \quad f(x)=\frac{x^{4 m}}{2 m\left(x^{2 m}+x^{m}+1\right)^{2}}\)

question: The integral \(\int \frac{x d x}{2-x^{2}+\sqrt{2-x^{2}}}\) equals :
solution:
}
  \item (b) \(\mathrm{I}=\int \frac{x d x}{2-x^{2}+\sqrt{2-x^{2}}}\)


Put \(t=\sqrt{2-x^{2}}, \frac{d t}{d x}=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2-x^{2}}} \cdot(-2 x)\)\\
\(\Rightarrow-t d t=x d x\)

\(\therefore \quad \mathrm{I}=\int \frac{(-t) d t}{t^{2}+t}=-\int \frac{1}{t+1} d t=-\log |t+1|\)

=-\log \left|\sqrt{2-x^{2}}+1\right|+c
\]

question: If \(\int \frac{x^{2}-x+1}{x^{2}+1} e^{\cot ^{-1} x} d x=A(x) e^{\cot ^{-1} x}+C\), then \(A(x)\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (b) Let \(\mathrm{I}=\int \frac{x^{2}-x+1}{x^{2}+1} \cdot e^{\cot ^{-1} x} d x\)


Put \(x=\cot t \Rightarrow-\operatorname{cosec}^{2} t d t=d x\)

Now, \(1+\cot ^{2} t=\operatorname{cosec}^{2} t\)

\(\therefore \quad \mathrm{I}=\int \frac{e^{t}\left(\cot ^{2} t-\cot t+1\right)}{\left(1+\cot ^{2} t\right)}\left(-\operatorname{cosec}^{2} t\right) d t\)

\(=-\int e^{t}\left(\operatorname{cosec}^{2} t-\cot t\right) d t\)

\(=\int e^{t}\left(\cot t-\operatorname{cosec}^{2} t\right) d t=e^{t} \cot t+\mathrm{C}\)

\(=e^{\cot ^{-1} x}(x)+\mathrm{C} \equiv \mathrm{A}(x) \cdot e^{\cot ^{-1} x}+\mathrm{C}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{A}(x)=x\)

question: If \(\int \frac{d x}{x+x^{7}}=p(x)\) then, \(\int \frac{x^{6}}{x+x^{7}} d x\) is equal to:

solution:

\(=\int\left[\frac{1}{\left(1+(\log x)^{2}\right)}-\frac{2 \log x}{\left(1+(\log x)^{2}\right)^{2}}\right] d x\)

\(\therefore \quad \mathrm{I}=\int\left[\frac{e^{t}}{1+t^{2}}-\frac{2 t e^{t}}{\left(1+t^{2}\right)^{2}}\right] d t\)

\(=\int e^{t}\left[\frac{1}{1+t^{2}}-\frac{2 t}{\left(1+t^{2}\right)^{2}}\right] d t\)

[Which is of the form \(\int e^{x}\left(f(x)+f^{\prime}(x)\right) d x\)

\left.=f(x) \cdot e^{x}+c\right]
\]

\(=\frac{e^{t}}{1+t^{2}}+c=\frac{x}{1+(\log x)^{2}}+c\)

question: If \(\mathrm{I}_{1}=\int_{0}^{1}\left(1-x^{50}\right)^{100} d x\) and \(\mathrm{I}_{2}=\int_{0}^{1}\left(1-x^{50}\right)^{101} d x\) such that \(\mathrm{I}_{2}=\alpha \mathrm{I}_{1}\) then \(\alpha\) equals to :
The value of \(\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{1}{1+e^{\sin x}} d x\) is:
solution:
}
  \item (c) \(I=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{1}{1+e^{\sin x}} d x\)


\(=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{0} \frac{1}{1+e^{\sin x}} d x+\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{1}{1+e^{\sin x}} d x\)

\(=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(\frac{1}{1+e^{\sin x}}+\frac{1}{1+e^{-\sin x}}\right) d x\)

\(=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{1+e^{\sin x}}{1+e^{\sin x}} d x=\frac{\pi}{2}\)

question: Let \(f(x)=|x-2|\) and \(g(x)=f(f(x)), x \in[0,4]\). \(\int_{0}^{4} g(x) d x\) =
solution: (a) \(f(x)=|x-2|= \begin{cases}2-x, & x<2 \\ x-2, & x \geq 2\end{cases}\)\ \(g(x)=f(f(x))= \begin{cases}2-f(x), & f(x)<2 \\ f(x)-2, & f(x) \geq 2\end{cases}\)\ \(=\left\{\begin{array}{lll}2-(2-x), & 2-x<2, & x<2 \\ (2-x)-2, & 2-x \geq 2, & x<2 \\ 2-(x-2), & x-2<2, & x \geq 2 \\ (x-2)-2, & x-2 \geq 2, & x \geq 2\end{array}\right.\)\ \(=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}-x & 0<x \leq 0 \\ x & 0<x<2 \\ 4-x & 2 \leq x<4 \\ x-4 & x \geq 4\end{array}\right.\)\ \(\therefore \int_{0}^{3}[g(x)-f(x)] d x\)\ \(=\int_{0}^{2} x d x+\int_{2}^{3}(4-x) d x-\int_{0}^{3}|x-2| d x=1\)

question: The integral \(\int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \tan ^{3} x \cdot \sin ^{2} 3 x\left(2 \sec ^{2} x \cdot \sin ^{2} 3 x+3 \tan x \cdot \sin 6 x\right) d x\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (c) \(\int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3}\left[\frac{1}{2} \frac{d\left(\tan ^{4} x\right)}{d x} \cdot \sin ^{4} 3 x+\frac{1}{2} \tan ^{4} x \cdot \frac{d\left(\sin ^{4} 3 x\right)}{d x}\right] d x\)


\(=\frac{1}{2} \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} d\left(\tan ^{4} x \cdot \sin ^{4} 3 x\right) d x\)

\(=\left[\frac{\tan ^{4} x \sin ^{4} 3 x}{2}\right]_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3}=\frac{9 \cdot 0}{2}-\frac{\frac{1}{9} \cdot 1}{2}=\frac{-1}{18}\)

question: Let \(\{x\}\) and \([x]\) denote the fractional part of \(x\) and the greatest integer \(\leq x\) respectively of a real number \(x\). If \(\int_{0}^{n}\{x\} d x, \int_{0}^{n}[x] d x\) and \(10\left(n^{2}-night),(n \in \mathbf{N}, n>1)\) are three consecutive terms of a G.P., then \(n\) is equal to \(\qquad\) .
solution:
}
  \item (21)


\(\int_{0}^{n}\{x\} d x=n \int_{0}^{1} x \cdot d x=\frac{n}{2}\)\\
\(\Rightarrow \int_{0}^{n}[x] d x=\int_{0}^{n}(x-\{x\}) d x=\frac{n^{2}}{2}-\frac{n}{2}\)

According to the questions,

\(\frac{n}{2}, \frac{n^{2}-n}{2}, 10\left(n^{2}-n\right)\) are in GP

\(\therefore\left(\frac{n^{2}-n}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{n}{2} \times 10\left(n^{2}-n\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow n^{2}=21 n \Rightarrow n=21\).

question: \(\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}|\pi-| x|| d x\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (c) \(I=\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}|\pi-| x|| d x \quad[\because|\pi-| x||\) is even \(]\)


\(=2 \int_{0}^{\pi}|\pi-| x|| d x\)

\(=2 \int_{0}^{\pi}(\pi-x) d x\)

\(=2\left[\pi x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right]_{0}^{\pi}=2\left(\pi^{2}-\frac{\pi^{2}}{2}\right)=\pi^{2}\).

question: If the value of the integral \(\int_{0}^{1 / 2} \frac{x^{2}}{\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}} d x\) is \(\frac{k}{6}\), then \(k\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(\frac{k}{6}=\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}} \frac{x^{2}}{\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}} d x\)


Let \(x=\sin \theta ; d x=\cos \theta d \theta\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \text { then } \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}} \frac{x^{2}}{\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}} d x=\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{6}} \frac{\sin ^{2} \theta \cos \theta}{\cos ^{3} \theta} d \theta \\
& \therefore \frac{k}{6}=\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{6}} \frac{\sin ^{2} \theta}{\cos ^{3} \theta} \cdot \cos \theta d \theta \\
& \Rightarrow \frac{k}{6}=\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{6}} \tan ^{2} \theta d \theta=\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{6}}\left(\sec ^{2} \theta-1\right) d \theta \\
& \Rightarrow \frac{k}{6}=(\tan \theta-\theta)_{0}^{\pi / 6}=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}-\frac{\pi}{6}\right)=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}-x}{6} \\
& \Rightarrow k=2 \sqrt{3}-\pi
\end{aligned}
\]

question: The integral \(\int_{0}^{2}|| x-1|-x| d x\) is equal to \(\qquad\) .
Let \([t]\) denote the greatest integer less than or equal to \(t\). Then the value of \(\int_{1}^{2}|2 x-[3 x]| d x\) is \(\qquad\) .
If for all real triplets \((a, b, c), f(x)=a+b x+c x^{2}\); then \(\int_{0}^{1} f(x) d x\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (d) \(\int_{0}^{1}\left(a+b x+c x^{2}\right) d x=a x+\frac{b x^{2}}{2}+\left.\frac{c x^{3}}{3}\right|_{0} ^{1}=a+\frac{b}{2}+\frac{c}{3}\)


Now, \(f(1)=a+b+c, f(0)=a\) and \(f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=a+\frac{b}{2}+\frac{c}{4}\)

Now, \(\frac{1}{6}\left(f(1)+f(0)+4 f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right)\)

\(=\frac{1}{6}\left(a+b+c+a+4\left(a+\frac{b}{2}+\frac{c}{4}\right)\right)\)

\(=\frac{1}{6}(6 a+3 b+2 c)=a+\frac{b}{2}+\frac{c}{3}\)

Hence, \(\int_{0}^{1} f(x)=\frac{1}{6}\left\{f(0)+f(1)+4 f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\right\}\)

question: The value of \(\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{x \sin ^{8} x}{\sin ^{8} x+\cos ^{8} x} d x\) is equal to:
If \(f(a+b+1-x)=f(x)\), for all \(x\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are fixed positive real numbers, then \(\frac{1}{a+b} \int_{a}^{b} x(f(x)+f(x+1)) d x\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (c) \(I=\frac{1}{(a+b)} \int_{a}^{b} x[f(x)+f(x+1)] d x\)


\(x \rightarrow a+b-x\)

\(I=\frac{1}{(a+b)} \int_{a}^{b}(a+b-x)[f(a+b-x)+f(a+b+1-x)] d x\)

\(I=\frac{1}{(a+b)} \int_{a}^{b}(a+b-x)[f(x+1)+f(x)] d x\)

\([\because\) put \(x \rightarrow x+1\) in \(f(a+b+\)

Add (i) and (ii)

\[
1-x)=f(x)]
\]

\(2 I=\int_{a}^{b}[f(x+1)+f(x)] d x\)

\(2 I=\int_{a}^{b} f(x+1) d x+\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x\)

\(=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b+1-x) d x+\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x\) \(2 I=2 \int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x\)

\(\therefore \int_{a-1}^{b-1} f(x+1) d x\)

\([\because\) Put \(x \rightarrow x+1]\)

question: The value of \(\alpha\) for which \(4 \alpha \int_{-1}^{2} e^{-\alpha|x|} d x=5\), is :
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(4 \alpha\left\{\int_{-1}^{0} e^{\alpha x} d x+\int_{0}^{2} e^{-\alpha x} d x\right\}=5\)


\(\Rightarrow 4 \alpha\left\{\left.\frac{e^{\alpha x}}{\alpha}\right|_{-1} ^{0}+\left.\frac{e^{-\alpha x}}{-\alpha}\right|_{0} ^{2}\right\}=5\)

\(\Rightarrow 4 \alpha\left\{\left(\frac{1-e^{-\alpha}}{\alpha}\right)-\left(\frac{e^{-2 \alpha}-1}{\alpha}\right)\right\}=5\)

\(\Rightarrow 4\left(2-e^{-\alpha}-e^{-2 \alpha}\right)=5\)

Put \(e^{-\alpha}=t\)

\(\Rightarrow 4 \mathrm{t}^{2}+4 \mathrm{t}-3=0 \quad \Rightarrow(2 \mathrm{t}+3)(2 \mathrm{t}-1)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow e^{-\alpha}=\frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow \alpha=\log _{e} 2\)

question: If \(\theta_{1}\) and \(\theta_{2}\) be respectively the smallest and the largest values of \(\theta\) in \((0,2 \pi)-\{\pi\}\) which satisfy the equation, \(2 \cot ^{2} \theta-\frac{5}{\sin \theta}+4=0\), then \(\int_{\theta_{1}}^{\theta_{2}} \cos ^{2} 3 \theta d \theta\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(2 \cot ^{2} \theta-\frac{5}{\sin \theta}+4=0\)


\(\frac{2 \cos ^{2} \theta}{\sin ^{2} \theta}-\frac{5}{\sin \theta}+4=0\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \cos ^{2} \theta-5 \sin \theta+4 \sin ^{2} \theta=0, \sin \theta \neq 0\)

\(\Rightarrow 2 \sin ^{2} \theta-5 \sin \theta+2=0\)

\(\Rightarrow(2 \sin \theta-1)(\sin \theta-2)=0\)

\(\therefore \sin \theta=\frac{1}{2} \quad \Rightarrow \theta=\frac{\pi}{6}, \frac{5 \pi}{6}\)

\(\therefore \quad \int_{\pi / 6}^{5 \pi / 6} \cos ^{2} 3 \theta d \theta=\int_{\pi / 6}^{5 \pi / 6} \frac{1+\cos 6 \theta}{2} d \theta\)

\(=\frac{1}{2}\left[\theta+\frac{\sin 6 \theta}{6}\right]_{\pi / 6}^{5 \pi / 6}=\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{5 \pi}{6}-\frac{\pi}{6}+\frac{1}{6}(0-0)\right]\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{4 \pi}{6}=\frac{\pi}{3}\)

question: Let \(f: \mathrm{R} \rightarrow \mathrm{R}\) be a continuously differentiable function such that \(f(2)=6\) and \(f^{\'} (2)=\frac{1}{48}\). If \(\int_{6}^{f(x)} 4 t^{3} d t=(x-2) g(x)\), then \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 2} g(x)\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (a) Given, \(\int_{6}^{f(x)} 4 t^{3} d t=(x-2) g(x)\)


Differentiating both sides,

\(4(f(x))^{3} \cdot f^{\prime}(x)=g^{\prime}(x)(x-2)+g(x)\)

Putting \(x=2, \frac{4(6)^{3} \cdot 1}{48}=g(2) \Rightarrow \lim _{x \rightarrow 2} g(x)=18\)

question: If \(\int_{0}^{\frac{x}{2}} \frac{\cot x}{\cot x+\operatorname{cosec} x} d x=m(\pi+n)\), then m.n is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (d) \(\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cot x d x}{\cot x+\operatorname{cosec} x}\)


\(=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cot x d x}{1+\cos x}=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(1-\frac{1}{1+\cos x}\right) d x\)

\(=[x]_{0}^{\pi / 2}-\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{1}{2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} d x=\frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sec ^{2} \frac{x}{2} d x\)

\(=\frac{\pi}{2}-\left(\tan \frac{x}{2}\right)_{0}^{\pi / 2}=\frac{\pi}{2}-[1]=\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-1\right)=m \pi+m n\)

\(\therefore m=, n=-2\), Hence, \(m n=-1\)

question: The value of \(\int_{0}^{2 \pi}[\sin 2 x(1+\cos 3 x)] d x\), where \([t]\) denotes the greatest integer function, is:
The integral \(\int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \sec ^{2 / 3} x \operatorname{cosec}^{4 / 3} x d x\) is equal to :
solution:
}
  \item (c) Let, \(I=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \sec ^{\frac{2}{3}} x \cdot \operatorname{cosec}^{\frac{4}{3}} x d x=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6} \cos ^{\frac{\pi}{3}} x \cdot \sin ^{\frac{4}{3}} x}^{\frac{\pi}{3}}\) \(=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{1 d x}{\cos ^{2} x \cdot \tan ^{\frac{4}{3}} x}=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{\sec ^{2} x d x}{\tan ^{\frac{4}{3}} x}\)


Let \(\tan x=u\)

\(I=\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{\sqrt{3}} u^{-\frac{4}{3}} d u=\frac{3\left[u^{-\frac{1}{3}}\right]}{-1}\)

\(=-3\left[3^{-\frac{1}{6}}-\frac{1}{3^{\frac{-1}{6}}}\right]=-3\left(3^{\frac{-1}{6}}-3^{\frac{1}{6}}\right)\)

\(=3\left(3^{\frac{1}{6}}-3^{\frac{1}{6}}\right)=\left(3^{\frac{7}{6}}-3^{\frac{5}{6}}\right)\)\\

question: The value of \(\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\sin ^{3} x}{\sin x+\cos x} d x\) is:
solution:
\item (b) Let \(I=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\sin ^{3} x d x}{\sin x+\cos x}\)

Use the property \(\int_{0}^{a} f(x) d x=\int_{0}^{a} f(a-x) d x\)

\(I=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cos ^{3} x d x}{\sin x+\cos x}\)

Adding equation (1) and (2), we get

\(\Rightarrow 2 I=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(1-\frac{1}{2} \sin (2 x)\right) d x\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\frac{1}{2}\left[x+\frac{1}{4} \cos 2 x\right]_{0}^{\pi / 2}\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\frac{\pi-1}{4}\)

question: The value of the integral \(\int_{0}^{1} x \cot ^{-1}\left(1-x^{2}+x^{4}\right) d x\) is
solution:
}
  \item (0) \(\int_{0}^{1} x \cot ^{-1}\left(1-x^{2}+x^{4}\right) d x=\int_{0}^{1} x \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{1+x^{4}-x^{2}}\right)\)


\(=\int_{0}^{1} x \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{x^{2}-\left(x^{2}-1\right)}{1+x^{2}\left(x^{2}-1\right)}\right) d x\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{1} 1 \tan ^{-1} t^{2} d t-\frac{1}{2} \int_{-1}^{0} 1 \tan ^{-1} k d k\)

Put \(x^{2}=t \Rightarrow 2 x d x=d t\) in the first integral

and \(x^{2}-1=k \Rightarrow 2 x d x=d k\) in the second integral.

\[
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{1} 1 \tan ^{-1} t d t-\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{1} 1 \tan ^{-1} k d k \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left(\left.t \tan ^{-1} t\right|_{0} ^{1}-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t}{1+t^{2}} d t\right)
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\begin{array}{r}
-\frac{1}{2}\left(\left.k \tan ^{-1} k\right|_{0} ^{1}-\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{k}{1+k^{2}} d k\right) \\
=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\left(\left.\frac{1}{2} \ln \left(1+t^{2}\right)\right|_{0} ^{1}\right)-\frac{1}{2}\left(-\frac{\pi}{4}-\left(\left.\frac{1}{2} \ln \left(1+k^{2}\right)\right|_{-1} ^{0}\right)\right)\right. \\
=\left(\frac{\pi}{8}-\frac{1}{4} \ln 2\right)-\left(\frac{-\pi}{8}-\frac{1}{4} 10-\ln 2\right)=\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{2} \ln 2
\end{array}
\]

question: If \(f: \mathrm{R} \rightarrow \mathrm{R}\) is a differentiable function and \(f(2)=6\), then \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 2} \int_{6}^{f(x)} \frac{2 t d t}{(x-2)}\) is:
solution:
}
  \item (d) Using L' Hospital rule and Leibnitz theorem, we get


\(\lim _{x \rightarrow 2} \frac{\int_{6}^{f(x)} 2 t d t}{(x-2)}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 2} \frac{2 f(x) f^{\prime}(x)-0}{1}\)

Putting \(x=2,2 f(2) f^{\prime}(2)=12 f^{\prime}(2) \quad[\because f(2)=6]\)

question: If \(f(x)=\frac{2-x \cos x}{2+x \cos x}\) and \(g(x)=\log _{e} x,(\mathrm{x}>0)\) then the value of the integral \(\int_{-\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} g(f(x)) d x\) is :
solution:
}
  \item (d) \(g(f(x))=\log \left(\frac{2-x \cos x}{2+x \cos x}\right), x>0\)


Let \(I=\int_{-\pi / 4}^{\pi / 4} \log \left(\frac{2-x \cos x}{2+x \cos x}\right) d x\)

Use the property \(\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b-x) d x\)

Then, equation (i) becomes,

\(I=\int_{-\pi / 4}^{\pi / 4} \log \left(\frac{2+x \cos x}{2-x \cos x}\right) d x\)

Adding (i) and (ii)

\(2 I=\int_{-\pi / 4}^{\pi / 4} \log \left(\frac{2-x \cos x}{2+x \cos x} \cdot \frac{2+x \cos x}{2-x \cos x}\right) d x\)

\(2 I=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \log (1) d x=0\)

\(\Rightarrow I=0=\log 1\)

question: Let \(f(x)=\int_{0}^{x} g(t) d t\), where \(g\) is a non-zero even function. If \(f(x+5)=g(x)\), then \(\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t\) equals:
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(f(x)=\int_{0}^{x} g(g) d t\),


\(\because g\) is a non-zero even function.

\(\therefore g(-x)=g(x)\),

Given, \(f(x+5)=g(x)\)

From (i) \(f^{\prime}(x)=g(x)\)

Let, \(I=\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t\),

Put \(t=\lambda-5 \Rightarrow I=\int_{5}^{x+5} f(\lambda-5) d \lambda\)

\(\because f(x+5)=\mathrm{g}(x)\)

\(\Rightarrow f(-x+5)=g(-x)=g(x)\)

\(I=\int_{5}^{x+5} f(\lambda-5) d \lambda\) \(f(0)=0, g(x)\) is even \(\Rightarrow f(x)\) is odd

\(\therefore I=\int_{5}^{x+5}-f(5-\lambda) d \lambda\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\int_{5}^{x+5} g(\lambda) d \lambda=\int_{x+5}^{5} g(t) d t\) (from(iv))

question: Let \(f\) and \(g\) be continuous functions on \([0, \mathrm{a}]\) such that \(f(x)=f(a-x)\) and \(g(x)+g(a-x)=4\), then \(\int_{0}^{a} f(x) g(x) d x\) is equal to:
solution: (c) \(f(x)=f(a-x)\)\ \(g(x)+g(a-x)=4\)\ Let, the integral,\ \(I=\int_{0}^{a} f(x) g(x) d x\)\ \(=\int_{0}^{a} f(a-x) \cdot g(a-x) d x\)\ \(\left[\because \int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b-x) d x\right]\)\ \(\Rightarrow I=\int_{0}^{a} f(x)[4-g(x)] d x\)\ \(\Rightarrow I=\int_{0}^{a} 4 f(x) d x-\int_{0}^{a} f(x) \cdot g(x) d x\)\ \(\Rightarrow I=\int_{0}^{a} 4 f(x) d x-I\)\ \(\Rightarrow 2 I=\int_{0}^{a} 4 f(x) d x\)\ \(\Rightarrow I=2 \int_{0}^{a} f(x) d x\)

question: The integral \(\int_{1}^{e}\left\{\left(\frac{x}{e}\right)^{2 x}-\left(\frac{e}{x}\right)^{x}\right\} \log _{e} x d x\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (d) \(I=\int_{1}^{e}\left\{\left(\frac{x}{e}\right)^{2 x}-\left(\frac{e}{x}\right)^{x}\right\} \log _{e} x d x\)


Let \(\left(\frac{x}{e}\right)^{x}=t\)

\(\Rightarrow \quad x \ln \left(\frac{x}{e}\right)=\ln t\)

\(\Rightarrow x(\ln x-1)=\ln t\)

On differentiating both sides w.r. \(x\) we get

\(\ln x . d x=\frac{d t}{t}\)

When \(x=e\) then \(t=1\) and when \(x=1\) then \(t=\frac{1}{e}\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
& I=\int_{\frac{1}{e}}^{1}\left(t^{2}-\frac{1}{t}\right) \cdot \frac{d t}{t}=\int_{\frac{1}{e}}^{1}\left(t-\frac{1}{t^{2}}\right) d t \\
& =\left(\frac{t^{2}}{2}+\frac{1}{t}\right)_{\frac{1}{e}}^{1}=\left(\frac{1}{2}+1\right)-\left(\frac{1}{2 e^{2}}+e\right)=\frac{3}{2}-e-\frac{1}{2 e^{2}}
\end{aligned}
\]

question: The value of the integral \(\int_{-2}^{2} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{\left[\frac{x}{\pi}\right]+\frac{1}{2}} d x\) (where \([\mathrm{x}]\) denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\) ) is:
solution:
}
  \item (a) Let \(f(x)=\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{\left[\frac{x}{\pi}\right]+\frac{1}{2}}\)


So, \(f(-x)=\frac{\sin ^{2}(-x)}{\left[\frac{-x}{\pi}\right]+\frac{1}{2}} \quad \because[-x]=-1-[x]\)

\(\Rightarrow f(-x)=\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{-1-\left[\frac{x}{\pi}\right]+\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{-\frac{1}{2}-\left[\frac{x}{\pi}\right]}=-f(x)\)

\(\Rightarrow f(x)\) is odd function

Hence, \(\int_{-2}^{2} f(x) d x=0\)

question: The integral \(\int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 4} \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\sin 2 x\left(\tan ^{5} x+\cot ^{5} x\right)}\) equals:
solution:
}
  \item (b) \(\mathrm{I}=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \frac{d x}{\sin 2 x\left(\tan ^{5} x+\cot ^{5} x\right)}\)


\(=\frac{\pi}{6} \frac{\frac{\pi}{4}}{2 \frac{\tan ^{5} x \cdot \sec ^{2} x}{\sin x}\left(\left(\tan ^{5} x\right)^{2}+1\right)}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2} \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \frac{\tan ^{4} x \cdot \sec ^{2} x}{\left(\tan ^{5} x\right)^{2}+1} d x\).

Let \(\tan ^{4} x=t\).

\(5 \tan ^{4} x \cdot \sec ^{2} x d x=d t\).

When \(x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{4}\) then \(t \rightarrow 1\)

and \(x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{6}\) then \(t \rightarrow\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{5}\)

\(\therefore \quad \mathrm{I}=\frac{1}{10} \int_{\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)^{5}}^{\frac{d t}{t^{2}+1}}\)

\[
=\frac{1}{10}\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{9 \sqrt{3}}\right)\right)
\]

question: Let \(\mathrm{I}=\int_{\mathrm{a}}^{\mathrm{b}}\left(x^{4}-2 x^{2}\right) \mathrm{d} x\). If \(\mathrm{I}\) is minimum then the ordered pair \((\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{b})\) is:
solution:
}
  \item (d) \(I=\int_{a}^{b}\left(x^{4}-2 x^{2}\right) d x\)


\(\Rightarrow \frac{d I}{d x}=x^{4}-2 x^{2}=0\) (for minimum)

\(\Rightarrow x=0, \pm \sqrt{2}\)

Also, \(I=\left[\frac{x^{5}}{5}-\frac{2 x^{3}}{3}\right]_{a}^{b}\)\\
For \(\mathrm{a}=0, \mathrm{~b}=\sqrt{2}\)

\(I=\frac{-8 \sqrt{2}}{15}\)

For \(\mathrm{a}=-\sqrt{2}, \mathrm{~b}=0\)

\(I=\frac{-8 \sqrt{2}}{15}\).

For \(\mathrm{a}=\sqrt{2}, \mathrm{~b}=-\sqrt{2}\)

\(I=\frac{16 \sqrt{2}}{15}\).

For \(\mathrm{a}=-\sqrt{2}, \mathrm{~b}=\sqrt{2}\)

\(I=\frac{-16 \sqrt{2}}{15}\).

\(\therefore \quad I\) is minimum when \((a, b)=(-\sqrt{2}, \sqrt{2})\)

question: If \(\int_{0}^{x} f(\mathrm{t}) \mathrm{dt}=x^{2}+\int_{x}^{1} \mathrm{t}^{2} f(\mathrm{t}) \mathrm{dt}\), then \(f^{\prime}(1 / 2)\) is:
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t=x^{2}+\int_{x}^{1} t^{2} f(t) d t\)


\(\Rightarrow f(x)=2 x-x^{2} f(x)\)

\(\Rightarrow f(x)=\frac{2 x}{1+x^{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{2\left(1-x^{2}\right)}{\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{2}}\)

Then,

\(f^{\prime}(1 / 2)=\frac{2\left(1-\frac{1}{4}\right)}{\left(1+\frac{1}{4}\right)^{2}}=\frac{3}{2} \times \frac{16}{25}=\frac{24}{25}\)

question: The value of \(\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{d x}{[x]+[\sin x]+4}\), where \([t]\) denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to \(t\), is:
The value of \(\int_{0}^{\pi}|\cos x|^{3} \mathrm{~d} x\) is:
solution:
}
  \item (b) \(\mathrm{I}=\int_{0}^{\pi}|\cos x|^{3} d x\)


\(=2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{3} x d x\)

\(=\frac{2}{4} \int_{0}^{\pi / 2}(3 \cos x+\cos 3 x) d x\)

\(\left[\because \cos 3 \theta=4 \cos ^{3} \theta-3 \cos \theta\right]\)

\(=\frac{1}{2}\left[3 \sin x+\frac{\sin 3 x}{3}\right]_{0}^{\pi / 2}\)

\(=\frac{1}{2}\left(3-\frac{1}{3}\right)=\frac{4}{3}\)

question: Let \(f\) be a differentiable function from \(\mathbf{R}\) to \(\mathbf{R}\) such that \(| f(x) - f(y)|\leq 2| x- y|^{3 / 2}\), for all \(x, y, \in \mathbf{R}\). If \(f(0)=1\) then \(\int_{0}^{1} f^{2}(x) d x\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(\because f: R \rightarrow R\)


and \(|f(x)-f(y)| \leq 2 \cdot|x-y|^{3 / 2}\)

\(\Rightarrow\left|\frac{f(x)-f(y)}{x-y}\right| \leq 2 \sqrt{x-y}\)

\(\Rightarrow \lim _{x \rightarrow y}\left|\frac{f(x)-f(y)}{x-y}\right| \leq \lim _{x \rightarrow y} 2 \sqrt{x-y}\)

\(\Rightarrow\left|f^{\prime}(x)\right|=0\)

\(\therefore f(x)\) is a constant function.

Given \(f(0)=1 \Rightarrow f(x)=1\)

Hence, the integral

\(\int_{0}^{1} f^{2}(x) d x=\int_{0}^{1} 1 d x=[x]_{0}^{1}=1\)

question: If \(\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan \theta}{\sqrt{2 \mathrm{ksec} \theta}} \mathrm{d} \theta=1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\), then the value of \(\mathrm{k}\) is:
solution:
}
  \item (d) Let, \(I=\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan \theta}{\sqrt{2 k \sec \theta}} d \theta\)


\(=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 k}} \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\sin \theta}{\sqrt{\cos \theta}} d \theta\)

Let \(\cos \theta=t^{2}\)

\(\therefore \sin \theta d \theta=-2 t d t\)

Hence, integral becomes,

\(I=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 k}} \int_{1}^{\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}} \frac{-2 t d t}{t}\)

\(=\sqrt{\frac{2}{k}} \frac{\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}^{1} d t}{}\) \(=\sqrt{\frac{2}{k}}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\)

\(=\frac{\sqrt{2}-1}{\sqrt{k}}\)

\(=1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\) (Given)

\(\therefore k=2\)

question: The value of \(\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{1+2^{x}} d x\) is:
If \(f(x)=\int_{0}^{x} t(\sin x-\sin t) d t\) then:
solution:
}
  \item (a) \(f(x)=\int_{0}^{x} t(\sin x-\sin t) \cdot d t\)


\[
\begin{aligned}
& =\sin x \int_{0}^{x} t \cdot d t-\int_{0}^{x} t \sin t \cdot d t \\
& =\frac{x^{2}}{2} \sin x+[t \cos t]_{0}^{x}+\sin x
\end{aligned}
\]

\(\Rightarrow f(x)=\frac{x^{2}}{2} \sin x+x \cos x+\sin x\)

\(f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{x^{2}}{2} \cos x+2 \cos x\)

\(f^{\prime \prime}(x)=x \cos x-\frac{x^{2}}{2} \sin x-2 \sin x\)

\(f^{\prime \prime \prime}(x)=\cos x-2 x \sin x-\frac{x^{2}}{2} \cos x-2 \cos x\)

\(\therefore f^{\prime \prime \prime}(x)+f^{\prime}(x)=\cos x-2 x \sin x\)

question: The value of integral \(\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}} \frac{x}{1+\sin x} d x\) is:
solution:
}
  \item (a) Let \(I=\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}} \frac{x}{1+\sin x} d x\)


also let \(K=\frac{x}{1+\sin x}\)

Multiplying numerator and denominator by \((1-\sin x)\), we get;\\
\(K=\frac{x(1-\sin x)}{1-(\sin x)^{2}}=\frac{x(1-\sin x)}{(\cos x)^{2}}\)

\(=x(1-\sin x) \sec ^{2} x\)

\(=x \sec ^{2} x-x \sin x \sec ^{2} x=x \sec ^{2} x-x \tan x \sec x\)

Now, \(I=\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}} x \sec ^{2} x d x-\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}} x \sec x \tan x d x\)

\(=\left[x \tan x-\int \frac{d x}{d x} \tan x d x\right]_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}}-\left[x \sec x-\int \frac{d x}{d x} \sec x d x\right]_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}}\)

\(=[x \tan x-\ln |\sec x|]_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}}\)

\(-[x \sec x-\ln |\sec x+\tan x|]_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}}+c\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\left\{\left[\frac{3 \pi}{4} \tan \frac{3 \pi}{4}-\ln \left|\frac{3 \pi}{4}\right|\right.\right.\)

\(\left.-\left[\frac{3 \pi}{4} \sec \frac{3 \pi}{4}-\ln \left|\sec \frac{3 \pi}{4}+\tan \frac{3 \pi}{4}\right|\right]\right\}\)

\(-\left\{\left[\frac{\pi}{4} \tan \frac{\pi}{4}-\ln \left|\frac{\pi}{4}\right|\right.\right.\)

\(\left.-\left[\frac{\pi}{4} \sec \frac{\pi}{4}-\ln \left|\sec \frac{\pi}{4}+\tan \frac{\pi}{4}\right|\right]\right\}\)

\(=\frac{\pi}{2}(\sqrt{2}+1)\)

question: The value of the integral \(\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin ^{4} x\left(1+\log \left(\frac{2+\sin x}{2-\sin x}\right)\right) d x\) is:
solution:
}
  \item (c) Let


\(I=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin ^{4} x\left(1+\log \left(\frac{2+\sin x}{2-\sin x}\right)\right) d x\). \(\left.\Rightarrow I=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin ^{4}(-x)\right)\left(1+\log \left(\frac{2+\sin (-x)}{2-\sin (-x)}\right)\right) \cdot d x\)

\(=\left[\because \int_{a}^{b} f(x) \cdot d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b-x) \cdot d x\right]\)

\(=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\left(\sin ^{4} x\right)\left(1+\log \left(\frac{2-\sin x}{2+\sin x}\right)\right) \cdot d x\)

\(=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin ^{4} x\left(1-\log \left(\frac{2+\sin x}{2-\sin x}\right)\right) \cdot d x\)

After adding equation (1) and (2) we get,

\(2 I=2 \int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin ^{4} x \cdot d x\)

\(2 I=4 \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin ^{4} x \cdot d x\)

\(I=2 \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin ^{4} x . d x=\frac{2 \times \frac{3}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \pi}{2 \times 2}=\frac{3 \pi}{8}\)

[By Gamma function]

question: The integral \(\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}} \frac{d x}{1+\cos x}\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (c) \(I=\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}} \frac{d x}{1+\cos x}\)


\(I=\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}} \frac{d x}{1-\cos x}\)

\(\operatorname{Using} \int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b-x) d x\)

Adding (i) and (ii)

\(2 I=\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}} \frac{2}{\sin ^{2} x} d x ; I=\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{3 \pi}{4}} \operatorname{cosec}^{2} x d x\)

\(I=-(\cot x)_{\pi / 4}^{3 \pi / 4}=-\left[\cot \frac{3 \pi}{4}-\cot \frac{\pi}{4}\right]=2\)

question: Let \(\mathrm{I}_{n}=\int \tan ^{\mathrm{n}} \mathrm{xdx},(\mathrm{n}>1) \cdot \mathrm{I}_{4}+\mathrm{I}_{6}=\mathrm{a}_{\tan ^{5} \mathrm{x}}+\mathrm{bx}^{5}+\mathrm{C}\), where \(\mathrm{C}\) is constant of integration, then the ordered pair \((\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{b})\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (c) \(I_{n}=\int \tan ^{n} x d x, n>1\)


Let \(\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{I}_{4}+\mathrm{I}_{6}\)

\(=\int\left(\tan ^{4} x+\tan ^{6} x\right) d x=\int \tan ^{4} x \sec ^{2} x d x\)

Let \(\tan x=t\)

\(\Rightarrow \sec ^{2} \mathrm{xdx}=\mathrm{dt}\)

\(\therefore I=\int t^{4} d t=\frac{t^{5}}{5}+C\)

\(=\frac{1}{5} \tan ^{5} x+C \Rightarrow\) On comparing, we have

\(\mathrm{a}=\frac{1}{5}, \mathrm{~b}=0\)

question: If \(\int_{1}^{2} \frac{d x}{\left(x^{2}-2 x+4\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}}=\frac{k}{k+5}\) then \(k\) is equal to:
solution:
}
  \item (a) Let \(\mathrm{I}=\int_{1}^{2} \frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\left((\mathrm{x}-1 \mathrm{a})^{2}+3\right)^{3 / 2}}\)


Let; \(\mathrm{x}-1=\sqrt{3} \tan \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{dx}=\sqrt{3} \sec ^{2} \cdot \mathrm{d} \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{I}=\int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \frac{\sqrt{3} \sec ^{2} \theta \mathrm{d} \theta}{\left((\sqrt{3} \tan \theta)^{2}+(\sqrt{3})^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}}\)

\(=\frac{1}{3} \int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \frac{\sec ^{2} \theta}{\sec ^{3} \theta} \mathrm{d} \theta=\frac{1}{3} \int_{0}^{\pi / 6} \cos \theta \mathrm{d} \theta\)

\(=\frac{1}{3}[\sin \theta]_{0}^{\pi / 6}=\frac{1}{3} \times \frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{6}\)

\(=\frac{1}{6}=\frac{k}{k+5} \Rightarrow k+5=6 k\)

\(\Rightarrow k=1\)

\(=\frac{1}{4} \int_{\pi / 12}^{\pi / 4} \sin 4 x \cdot(1-\cos 4 x) d x\)

\(=\frac{1}{4}\left[\int_{\frac{\pi}{12}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \sin 4 x-\frac{1}{2} \int_{\frac{\pi}{12}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \sin 8 x\right]\)

\(=\frac{1}{4}\left[-\frac{\cos 4 x}{4}+\frac{\cos 8 x}{16}\right]_{\pi / 12}^{\pi / 4}=\frac{1}{4}\left[\frac{15}{32}\right]=\frac{15}{128}\)
