question: The value of the integral \(\int_{6}^{16} \frac{\log _{e} x^{2}}{\log _{e} x^{2}+\log _{e}\left(x^{2}-44 x+484\right)} d x\) is:

If \(U_{n}=\left(1+\frac{1}{n^{2}}\right)\left(1+\frac{2^{2}}{n^{2}}\right)^{2} \ldots \left(1+\frac{n^{2}}{n^{2}}\right)^{n}\), then \(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(U_{n}\right)^{\frac{-4}{n^{2}}}\) is equal to:
solution:
\(U_{n}=\prod_{r=1}^{n}\left(1+\frac{r^{2}}{n^{2}}\right)^{r}\)

\(L=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(U_{n}\right)^{-4 / n^{2}}\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \log L=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{-4}{n^{2}} \sum_{r=1}^{n} \log \left(1+\frac{r^{2}}{n^{2}}\right)^{r} \\
& \Rightarrow \log L=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{r=1}^{n}-\frac{4 r}{n} \cdot \frac{1}{n} \log \left(1+\frac{r^{2}}{n^{2}}\right) \\
& \Rightarrow \log L=-4 \int_{0}^{1} x \log \left(1+x^{2}\right) d x
\end{aligned}
\]

put \(1+x^{2}=t\)

Now, \(2 x d x=d t\)

\(=-2 \int_{1}^{2} \log (t) d t=-2[t \log t-t]_{1}^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \log L=-2(2 \log 2-1)\)

\(\therefore L=e^{-2(2 \log 2-1)}\)

\(=e^{-2\left(\log \left(\frac{4}{e}\right)\right)}\)

\(=e^{\log \left(\frac{4}{e}\right)^{2}}\)

\(=\left(\frac{e}{4}\right)^{2}=\frac{e^{2}}{16}\)

question: The value of \(\int_{\frac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}\left(\left(\frac{x+1}{x-1}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{x-1}{x+1}\right)^{2}-2\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} d x\) is:
solution:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& I=\int_{\frac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}\left(\left(\frac{x+1}{x-1}-\frac{x-1}{x+1}\right)^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} d x \\
& I=\int_{\frac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}\left|\frac{4 x}{x^{2}-1}\right| d x \Rightarrow I=2.4 \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}\left|\frac{x}{x^{2}-1}\right| d x \\
& \Rightarrow I=-4 \int_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \frac{2 x}{x^{2}-1} d x \Rightarrow I=-4 \ln \left|x^{2}-1\right|_{0}^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \\
& \Rightarrow I=4 \ln 2 \Rightarrow I=\ln 16
\end{aligned}
\]

question: If the area of the bounded region \(R=\left\{(x, y): \max \left\{0, \log _{e} x\right\} \leq y \leq 2^{x}, \frac{1}{2} \leq x \leq 2\right\}\) is, \(\alpha\left(\log _{e} 2\right)^{-1}+\beta\left(\log _{e} 2\right)+\gamma\), then the value of \((\alpha+\beta-2 \gamma)^{2}\) is equal to:
solution:
\[
R=\left\{(x, y): \max \left\{0, \log _{e} x\right\} \leq y \leq 2^{x}, \frac{1}{2} \leq x \leq 2\right\}
\]

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_06_11_5bae6af2ed6dc69baf79g-085}
\end{center}

\(\int_{\frac{1}{2}}^{2} 2^{x} d x-\int_{1}^{2} \ln x d x\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{2^{x}}{\ln 2}\right]_{1 / 2}^{2}-[x \ln x-x]_{1}^{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\left(2^{2}\right)-2^{1 / 2}}{\log _{e} 2}-(2 \ln 2-1)\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\left(2^{2}-\sqrt{2}\right)}{\log _{e} 2}-2 \ln 2+1\)

\(\therefore \alpha=2^{2}-\sqrt{2}, \beta=-2, \gamma=1\)

\(\therefore(\alpha+\beta+2 \gamma)^{2}\)

\(=\left(2^{2}-\sqrt{2}-2-2\right)^{2}\)

\(=(\sqrt{2})^{2}=2\)

question: The value of the definite integral \(\int_{-\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \frac{d x}{\left(1+e^{x \cos x}\right)\left(\sin ^{4} x+\cos ^{4} x\right)}\) is equal to:
solution:
\(I=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \frac{d x}{\left(1+e^{x \cos x}\right)\left(\sin ^{4} x+\cos ^{4} x\right)} \ldots\).

Using \(\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b-x) d x\)

\(I=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \frac{d x}{\left(1+e^{-x \cos x}\right)\left(\sin ^{4} x+\cos ^{4} x\right)}\)

Add (1) and (2)

\(2 I=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \frac{d x}{\sin ^{4} x+\cos ^{4} x}\)

\(2 I=2 \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \frac{d x}{\sin ^{4} x+\cos ^{4} x}\)

\(I=\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \frac{\left(1+\frac{1}{\tan ^{2} x}\right) \sec ^{2} x}{\left(\tan -\frac{1}{\tan x}\right)^{2}+2} d x\)

\(\tan x-\frac{1}{\tan x}=t\)

\(\left(1+\frac{1}{\tan ^{2} x}\right) \sec ^{2} x d x=d t\)

\(I=\int_{-\infty}^{0} \frac{d t}{t^{2}+2}=\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{t}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\right]_{-\infty}^{0}\)

\(I=0-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left(-\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\frac{\pi}{2 \sqrt{2}}\)

question: The value of \(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{(2 j-1)+8 n}{(2 j-1)+4 n}\) is equal to:
solution:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{\left(\frac{2 j}{n}-\frac{1}{n}+8\right)}{\left(\frac{2 j}{n}-\frac{1}{n}+4\right)} \\
& \int_{0}^{1} \frac{2 x+8}{2 x+4} d x=\int_{0}^{1} d x+\int_{0}^{1} \frac{4}{2 x+4} d x \\
& =1+4 \frac{1}{2}(\ln |2 x+4|)_{0}^{1} \\
& =1+2 \ln \left(\frac{3}{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
\]

question: Let \(f:(a, b) \rightarrow R\) be twice differentiable function such that \(f(x)=\int_{a}^{x} g(t) d t\) for a differentiable function \(g(x)\). If \(f(x)=0\) has exactly five distinct roots in \((a, b)\), then \(g(x) g^{\prime}(x)=0\) has at least:
solution:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& f(x)=\int_{a}^{x} g(t) d t \\
& \Rightarrow \mathrm{f}^{\prime}(\mathrm{x})=\mathrm{g}(\mathrm{x}) \\
& \Rightarrow \mathrm{f}^{\prime \prime}(\mathrm{x})=\mathrm{g}^{\prime}(\mathrm{x})
\end{aligned}
\]

Given, \(g(x) \cdot g^{\prime}(x)=0\)

\(\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x) \cdot f^{\prime \prime}(x)=0\)

Also given \(f(x)\) has exactly 5 roots.

So from Rolle's theorem we can say,

\(f^{\prime}(x)\) has 4 roots and \(f^{\prime \prime}(x)\) has 3 roots.

\(\therefore f^{\prime}(x) \cdot f^{\prime \prime}(x)=0\) has \(4+3=7\) roots.

question: The area of the region bounded by \(y-x=2\) and \(x^{2}=y\) is equal to:
Where \([x]\) is the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\). Which of the following is true?
options: f is continuous at every point in \([0, \infty)\) and differentiable except at the integer points.
f is both continuous and differentiable except at the integer points in \([0, \infty)\).
f is continuous everywhere except at the integer points in \([0, \infty)\).
f is differentiable at every point in \([0, \infty)\).
solution:
\(f:[0, \infty) \rightarrow[0, \infty), f(x)=\int_{0}^{x}[y] d y\)

Let \(x=n+f, f \in(0,1)\)

So, \(f(x)=0+1+2+\ldots+(n-1)+\int_{n}^{n+f} n d y\)

\(f(x)=\frac{n(n-1)}{2}+n f\)

\(=\frac{[x]([x]-1)}{2}+[x]\{x\}\)

Note \(\lim _{x \rightarrow n^{+}} f(x)=\frac{n(n-1)}{2}, \lim _{x \rightarrow n^{-}} f(x)=\frac{(n-1)(n-2)}{2}+(n-1)\)

\(=\frac{n(n-1)}{2}\)

\(f(x)=\frac{n(n-1)}{2}\left(n \in N_{0}\right)\)

so \(f(x)\) is cont. \(\forall x \geq 0\) nd diff. except at integer points

question: The area (in sq units) of the region, given by the set \(\left\{(x, y) \in R \times R \mid x \geq 0,2 x^{2} \leq y \leq 4-2 x\right\}\) is:
The value of the definite integral \(\int_{\pi / 24}^{5 \pi / 24} \frac{d x}{1+\sqrt[3]{\tan 2 x}}\) is:
solution:
\[
\text { Let } I=\int_{\pi / 24}^{5 \pi / 24} \frac{(\cos 2 x)^{1 / 3}}{(\cos 2 x)^{1 / 3}+(\sin 2 x)^{1 / 3}} d x \ldots \ldots
\]

\(\Rightarrow I=\int_{\pi / 2}^{5 \pi / 24} \frac{\left(\cos \left\{2\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-x\right)\right\}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}}{\left(\cos \left\{2\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-x\right)\right\}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}+\left(\sin \left\{2\left(\frac{\pi}{4}-x\right)\right\}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}} d x\left\{\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b-x) d x\right\}\)

So, \(I=\int_{\pi / 24}^{5 \pi / 24} \frac{(\sin 2 x)^{1 / 3}}{(\sin 2 x)^{1 / 3}+(\sin 2 x)^{1 / 3}} d x \ldots\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Hence, } 2 I=\int_{\pi / 24}^{5 \pi / 24} d x[(\mathrm{i})+(\mathrm{ii})] \\
& \Rightarrow 2 I=\frac{4 \pi}{24} \Rightarrow I=\frac{\pi}{12}
\end{aligned}
\]

question: If \(\int_{0}^{100 \pi} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{e^{\left(\frac{x}{\pi}-\left[\frac{x}{\pi}\right]\right)}} d x=\frac{\alpha \pi^{3}}{1+4 \pi^{2}}, \alpha \in R\) where \([x]\) is the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\), then the value of \(\alpha\) is:
solution:
\[
I=\int_{0}^{100 \pi} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{e^{\left(\frac{x}{\pi}-\left[\frac{x}{\pi}\right]\right)}} d x
\]

\(\because\) Integrand is periodic with period 1

\[
\therefore I=100 \int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{e^{\left.\frac{x}{\pi}\right\}}} d x
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Let } \frac{x}{\pi}=t \Rightarrow d x=\pi d t \\
& =100 \pi \int_{0}^{1} \frac{\sin ^{2}(\pi t) d t}{e^{t}} \\
& =50 \pi \int_{0}^{1} e^{-t}(1-\cos 2 \pi t) d t \\
& =50 \pi \int_{0}^{1} e^{-t} d t-50 \pi \int_{0}^{1} e^{-t} \cos (2 \pi t) d t \\
& =-50\left[e^{-t}\right]_{0}^{1}-50 \pi\left[\frac{e^{-t}}{1+4 \pi^{2}}(-\cos 2 \pi t+2 \pi \sin 2 \pi t)\right]_{0}^{1} \\
& =-50 \pi\left(e^{-1}-1\right)-\frac{50 \pi}{1+4 \pi^{2}}\left(e^{-1}(-1+0)-(-1+0)\right) \\
& =-50 \pi\left(e^{-1}-1\right)-\frac{50 \pi\left(1-e^{-1}\right)}{1+4 \pi^{2}}
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
=\frac{200 \pi^{3}\left(1-e^{-1}\right)}{1+4 \pi^{2}}=\frac{\alpha \pi^{3}}{1+4 \pi^{3}} \text { (Given) }
\]

\(\therefore \alpha=200\left(1-e^{-1}\right)\)

question: Let \(g(t)=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4} t+f(x)\right) d x\), where \(f(x)=\log _{e}\left(x+\sqrt{x^{2}+1}\right), x \in R\). Then which one of the following is correct?
solution:
\(\because f(x)=\ln \left(x+\sqrt{x^{2}+1}\right)\)

\(\therefore f(x)+f(-x)=\ln \left(\sqrt{x^{2}+1}+x\right)+\ln \left(\sqrt{x^{2}+1}-x\right)\)

\(\therefore f(x)+f(-x)=0\)

\(\because g(t)=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4} t+f(x)\right) d x\)

\(=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left\{\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4} t+f(x)\right)+\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{4} t+f(-x)\right)\right\} d x\)

\(=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left\{\cos \left(\frac{\pi t}{4}+f(x)\right)+\cos \left(\frac{\pi t}{4}-f(x)\right)\right\} d x\)

\(g(t)=2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos \frac{\pi t}{4} \cdot \cos (f(x)) d x\)

\(\therefore g(1)=\sqrt{2} \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos (f(x)) d x\) and

\(g(0)=2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos (f(x)) d x\)

\(\therefore \sqrt{2} g(1)=g(0)\)

question: Let \(y=y(x)\) satisfies the equation \(\frac{d y}{d x}-|A|=0\), for all \(x>0\), where \(A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}y & \sin x & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 1 \\ 2 & 0 & \frac{1}{x}\end{array}\right]\). If \(y(\pi)=\pi+2\), then the value of \(y\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\) is:
solution:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& |A|=-\frac{y}{x}+2 \sin x+2 \\
& \frac{d y}{d x}=|A| \\
& \frac{d y}{d x}=-\frac{y}{x}+2 \sin x+2 \\
& \frac{d y}{d x}+\frac{y}{x}=2 \sin x+2 \\
& I . F .=e^{\int \frac{1}{x} d x}=x \\
& \Rightarrow y x=\int x(2 \sin x+2) d x \\
& x y=x^{2}-2 x \cos x+2 \sin x+c \ldots
\end{aligned}
\]

Now, \(\mathrm{x}=\pi, \mathrm{y}=\pi+2\)

Use in (i)

\(c=0\)

Now, (i) becomes\\
\(x y=x^{2}-2 x \cos x+2 \sin x\)

put \(x=\pi / 2\)

\(\frac{\pi}{2} y=\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)^{2}-2 \cdot \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{2}+2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2}\)

\(y\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\frac{\pi^{2}}{4}+2\)

question: If the real part of the complex number \((1-\cos \theta+2 i \sin \theta)^{-1}\) is \(\frac{1}{5}\) for \(\theta \in(0, \pi)\), then the value of the integral \(\int_{0}^{\theta} \sin x d x\) is equal to:
solution:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& z=\frac{1}{1-\cos \theta+2 i \sin \theta} \\
& =\frac{2 \sin ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}-2 i \sin \theta}{(1-\cos \theta)^{2}+4 \sin ^{2} \theta} \\
& =\frac{\sin \frac{\theta}{2}-2 i \cos \frac{\theta}{2}}{2 \sin \frac{\theta}{2}\left(\sin ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}+4 \cos ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}\right)}
\end{aligned}
\]

\(\operatorname{Re}(z)=\frac{1}{2\left(\sin ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}+4 \cos ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}\right)}=\frac{1}{5}\)

\(\sin \frac{2 \theta}{2}+4 \cos ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}=\frac{5}{2} 1-\cos ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}+4 \cos \frac{\theta}{2}=\frac{5}{2}\)

\(3 \cos ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}=\frac{1}{2}\)

\(\frac{\theta}{2}=n \pi \pm \frac{\pi}{4}\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \theta=2 n \pi \pm \frac{\pi}{2} \\
& \theta \in(0, \pi) \\
& \therefore \theta=\frac{\pi}{2} \\
& \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin \theta d \theta=[-\cos \theta]_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \\
& =-(0-1) \\
& =1
\end{aligned}
\]

question: If \([x]\) denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\), then the value of the integral \(\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2}[[x]-\sin x] d x\) is equal to:
The value of the integral \(\int_{-1}^{1} \log _{e}(\sqrt{1-x}+\sqrt{1+x}) d x\) is equal to:
solution: NULL

question: Let a be a positive real number such that \(\int_{0}^{a} e^{x-[x]} d x=10 e-9\) where \([x]\) is the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\). Then a is equal to:
solution:
\(a>0\)

Let \(n \leq a<n+1, n \in W\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
& {[a] \quad+\quad\{a\}} \\
& a=\Downarrow \quad \Downarrow \\
& \text { G.I.F. } \quad \text { Fractional part }
\end{aligned}
\]

Here \([\mathrm{a}]=\mathrm{n}\)

Now, \(\int_{0}^{a} e^{x-[x]} d x=10 e-9\)

\(\Rightarrow \int_{0}^{n} e^{\{x\}} d x+\int_{n}^{a} e^{x-[x]} d x=10 e-9\)

\(\therefore n \int_{0}^{1} e^{x} d x+\int_{n}^{a} e^{x-n} d x=10 e-9\)

\(\Rightarrow n(e-1)+\left(e^{a-n}-1\right)=10 e-9\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{n}=0\) and \(\{\mathrm{a}\}=\log _{\mathrm{e}} 2\)

So, \(a=[a]+\{a\}=\left(10+\log _{e} 2\right)\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Option (2) is correct.

question: Let \(g(x)=\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t\), where \(f\) is continuous function in \([0,3]\) such that \(\frac{1}{3} \leq f(t) \leq 1\) for all \(t\) in \([0,1]\) and 0 \(\leq f(t) \leq \frac{1}{2}\) for all \(t\) in \((1,3]\). The largest possible interval in which \(g(3)\) lies is:
solution: NULL

question: The area bounded by the curve \(4 y^{2}=x^{2}(4-x)(x-2)\) is equal to:
solution:
Given,

\(4 y^{2}=x^{2}(4-x)(x-2)\)

Here, Left hand side \(4 y^{2}\) is always positive. So Right hand side should also be positive.

In \(x \in[2,4]\) Right hand side is positive.

By putting \(y=-y\) in equation (1), equation remains same. So, graph is symmetric about \(\mathrm{x}\) axis.

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_06_11_5bae6af2ed6dc69baf79g-098}
\end{center}

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Required Area }=2 \mathrm{~A}_{1} \\
& =2 \int_{2}^{4} y d x \\
& =\int_{2}^{4} x \sqrt{(x-2)(4-x)} d x \\
& \text { put } x=4 \sin ^{2} \theta+2 \cos ^{2} \theta \\
& \Rightarrow d x=[4(2 \sin \theta \cos \theta-4 \sin \theta \cos \theta)] d \theta \\
& \Rightarrow d x=4 \sin \theta \cos \theta d \theta
\end{aligned}
\]

When lower limit \(=2\) then

\[
\begin{aligned}
& 2=4 \sin ^{2} \theta+2 \cos ^{2} \theta \\
& \Rightarrow 4\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right)+2 \cos ^{2} \theta=2 \\
& \Rightarrow 4-4 \cos ^{2} \theta+2 \cos ^{2} \theta=2 \\
& \Rightarrow 2 \cos ^{2} \theta=2 \\
& \Rightarrow \theta=0, \pi
\end{aligned}
\]

When upper limit \(=4\) then

\(4=4 \sin ^{2} \theta+2 \cos ^{2} \theta\)

\(\Rightarrow-2 \cos ^{2} \theta=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \theta=\frac{\pi}{2}\)

\(\therefore\) Range of \(\theta=0\) to \(\frac{\pi}{2}\)

\(\therefore\) Area \(=\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\left(4 \sin ^{2} \theta+2 \cos ^{2} \theta\right) \sqrt{\left(2 \sin ^{2} \theta\right)\left(2 \cos ^{2} \theta\right)}(4 \sin \theta \cos \theta) d \theta\)

\(=\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\left(4 \sin ^{2} \theta+2 \cos ^{2} \theta\right) 8 \sin ^{2} \theta \cos ^{2} \theta d \theta\)

\(=32 \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin ^{4} \theta \cos ^{2} \theta d \theta+16 \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \sin ^{2} \theta \cos ^{2} \theta d \theta\)

Using Wallis formula,\\
\(=32 \cdot \frac{3 \cdot 1 \cdot 1}{6.4 \cdot 2} \cdot \frac{\pi}{2}+16 \cdot \frac{1 \cdot 3 \cdot 1}{6.4 \cdot 2} \cdot \frac{\pi}{2}\)

\(=\pi+\frac{\pi}{2}\)

\(=\frac{3 \pi}{2}\)

question: If the integral \(\int_{0}^{10} \frac{[\sin 2 \pi x]}{e^{x-[x]}} d x=\alpha e^{-1}+\beta e^{-\frac{1}{2}}+\gamma\), where \(\alpha, \beta, \gamma\) are integers and \([x]\) denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\), then the value of \(\alpha+\beta+\gamma\) is equal to:
solution:
Given integral

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{10} \frac{[\sin 2 \pi x]}{e^{x-[x]}} d x=10 \int_{0}^{1} \frac{[\sin 2 \pi x]}{e^{\{x\}}} d x \text { (using property of definite in.) } \\
& =10\left[\int_{0}^{1 / 2} 0 . d x+\int_{1 / 2}^{1} \frac{-1}{e^{x}} d x\right] \\
& =-10\left[\frac{e^{-x}}{-1}\right]_{1 / 2}^{1}=10\left[e^{-1}-e^{-1 / 2}\right] \\
& =10 e^{-1}-10 e^{-1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
\]

comparing with the given relation,

\[
\alpha=10, \beta=-10, \gamma=0
\]

\(\alpha+\beta+\gamma=0\)

Therefore, the correct answer is (A).

question: Let \(f: R \rightarrow R\) be defined as \(f(x)=e^{-x} \sin x\). If \(F:[0,1] \rightarrow R\) is a differentiable function with that \(F(x)= \int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t\), then the value of \(\int_{0}^{1}\left(F^{\prime}(x)+f(x)\right) e^{x} d x\) lies in the interval:
solution:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{F}(\mathrm{x})=\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t \\
& \Rightarrow \mathrm{F}^{\prime}(\mathrm{x})=\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x}) \text { by Leibnitz theorem } \\
& \mathrm{I}=\int_{0}^{1}\left(F^{\prime}(x)+f(x)\right) e^{x} d x=\int_{0}^{1} 2 f(x) e^{x} d x \\
& I=\int_{0}^{1} 2 \sin x d x \\
& I=2(1-\cos 1) \\
& =2\left\{1-\left(1-\frac{1^{2}}{2!}+\frac{1}{24}\right)\right\} \\
& =2\left\{1-\left(1-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{24}-\frac{1}{720}\right)\right\} \\
& \frac{330}{360}<2(1-\cos 1)<\frac{331}{360} \\
& \frac{330}{360}<1<\frac{331}{360}
\end{aligned}
\]

question: Which of the following statements is incorrect for the function \(g(\alpha)\) for \(\alpha \in R\) such that \(g(\alpha)=\int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \frac{\sin ^{\alpha} x}{\cos ^{\alpha} x+\sin ^{\alpha} x} d x\)?
options: g(\alpha) is a strictly increasing function
g(\alpha) has an inflection point at \(\alpha=-\frac{1}{2}\)
g(\alpha) is a strictly decreasing function

question: Let \(P(x)=x^{2}+bx+c\) be a quadratic polynomial with real coefficients such that \(\int_{0}^{1} P(x) d x=1\) and \(P(x)\) leaves remainder 5 when it is divided by \((x-2)\). Then the value of \(9(b+c)\) is equal to:
solution:
\[
(x-2) Q(x)+5=x^{2}+b x+c
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Put } \mathrm{x}=2 \\
& 5=2 \mathrm{~b}+\mathrm{c}+4 \ldots \text { (1) } \\
& \int_{0}^{1}\left(x^{2}+b x+c\right) d x=1 \\
& \Rightarrow \frac{1}{3}+\frac{b}{2}+c=1 \\
& \frac{b}{2}+c=\frac{2}{3} \ldots .(2)
\end{aligned}
\]

Solve (1) \& (2)

\(b=\frac{2}{9}\)\\
\(c=\frac{5}{9}\)

\(9(b+c)=7\)

question: Consider the integral \(I=\int_{0}^{10} \frac{[x] e^{[x]}}{e^{x-1}} d x\) where \([x]\) denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\). Then the value of \(I\) is equal to:
For \(x>0\), if \(f(x)=\int_{1}^{x} \frac{\log _{e} t}{(1+t)} d t\), then \(f(e)+f\left(\frac{1}{e}\right)\) is equal to:
solution:
\[
f(x)=\int_{1}^{x} \frac{\ln t}{1+t} d t
\]

\[
\text { then } f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)=\int_{1}^{1 / x} \frac{\ln t}{1+t} d t
\]

Let \(t=\frac{1}{u} \Rightarrow d t=-\frac{1}{u^{2}} d u\)

\(\Rightarrow f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)=\int_{1}^{x} \frac{\ln \frac{1}{u}}{1+\frac{1}{u}}\left(-\frac{1}{u^{2}}\right) d x\)

\(f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)=\int_{1}^{x} \frac{\ln u}{u(1+u)} d u=\int_{1}^{x} \frac{\ln t}{t(1+t)} d t\)

\(\therefore f(x)+f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)=\int_{1}^{x} \ln t\left(\frac{1}{1+t}+\frac{1}{t}-\frac{1}{t+1}\right) d t\)\\
\(=\int_{1}^{x} \frac{\ln t}{t} d t=\frac{1}{2}(\ln x)^{2}\)

\(\therefore f(e)+f\left(\frac{1}{e}\right)=\frac{1}{2}(\ln e)^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\)

question: The value of \(\sum_{n=1}^{100} \int_{n=1}^{n} e^{x-[x]} d x\), where \([x]\) is the greatest integer \(\leq x\), is:
The value of \(\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cos ^{2} x}{1+3^{x}} d x\) is:
solution:
\[
\text { Let } I=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\cos ^{2} x}{1+3^{x}} d x
\]

Replace \(x\) with \(-x\),

\[
\therefore I=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\cos ^{2} x}{1+\frac{1}{3^{x}}} \cdots
\]

Adding (1) and (2), we get,

\[
\begin{aligned}
& 2 I=\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\cos ^{2} x\left(1+3^{x}\right)}{1+3^{x}} d x \\
& =\int_{-\frac{\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \cos ^{2} x d x
\end{aligned}
\]

[ \(\cos ^{2} x\) is a even function as \(f(x)=f(-x)\) for \(\cos ^{2} x\) ]

\(=2 \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \cos ^{2} x d x\)

\(=2 \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\left(\frac{1+\cos 2 x}{2}\right) d x\)

\(\Rightarrow I=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}(1+\cos 2 x) d x\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{1}{2}[x+\sin 2 x]_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{\pi}{2}-0\right] \\
& =\frac{\pi}{4}
\end{aligned}
\]

question: If \(I_{n}=\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \cot ^{n} x d x\), then:
solution:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& I_{n}=\int_{\pi / 4}^{\pi / 2} \cot ^{n} x d x=\int_{\pi / 4}^{\pi / 2} \cot ^{n-2} x\left(\operatorname{cosec}^{2} x-1\right) d x \\
& =\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \cot ^{n-2} x \cdot \operatorname{cosec}^{2} x d x-\int_{\frac{\pi}{4}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \cot ^{n-2} x d x \\
& \left.=\frac{\cot ^{n-1} x}{n-1}\right]_{\pi / 4}^{\pi / 2}-I_{n-2} \\
& =\frac{1}{n-1}-I_{n-2} \\
& \Rightarrow I_{n}+I_{n-2}=\frac{1}{n-1} \\
& \Rightarrow I_{2}+I_{4}=\frac{1}{3} \\
& I_{3}+I_{5}=\frac{1}{4} \\
& I_{4}+I_{6}=\frac{1}{5} \\
& \therefore \frac{1}{I_{2}+I_{4}}, \frac{1}{I_{3}+I_{5}}, \frac{1}{I_{4}+I_{6}} \text { are in A.P. }
\end{aligned}
\]

question: The value of \(\int_{-1}^{1} x^{2} e^{\left[x^{3}\right]} d x\), where \([t]\) denotes the greatest integer \(\leq t\), is:
solution:
\(I=\int_{-1}^{1} x^{2} e^{\left[x^{3}\right]} d x\)

Here \(-1 \leq x \leq 1\) then \(-1 \leq x^{3} \leq 1\)

Integer between -1 and 1 is 0 . So integration will be divided into two parts, -1 to 0 and 0 to 1 .

\(=\int_{-1}^{0} x^{2} e^{-1} d x+\int_{0}^{1} x^{2} e^{0} d x\)

\(=\\int_{-1}^{0} x^{2} e^{-1} d x+\int_{0}^{1} x^{2} e^{0} d x\)

\(=\frac{1}{e} \times\left[\frac{x^{3}}{3}\right]_{-1}^{0}+\left[\frac{x^{3}}{3}\right]_{0}^{1}\)

\(=\frac{1}{e} \times\left(0-\left(\frac{-1}{3}\right)\right)+\frac{1}{3}\)

\(=\frac{1}{3 e}+\frac{1}{3}=\frac{1+e}{3 e}\)

question: The area of the region: \(R=\left\{(x, y): 5 x^{2} \leq y \leq 2 x^{2}+9\right\}\) is:

Let \(f(x)\) be a differentiable function defined on \([0,2]\) such that \(f^{\prime}(x)=f^{\prime}(2-x)\) for all \(x\) in \((0,2)\), \(f(0)=1\) and \(f(2)=\mathrm{e}^{2}\). Then the value of \(\int_{0}^{2} f(x) d x\) is:
solution:
\(f^{\prime}(x)=f^{\prime}(2-x)\)

On integrating both side \(f(x)=-f(2-x)+c\)

put \(x=0\)

\(f(0)+f(2)=c \Rightarrow c=1+e^{2}\)

\[
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow f(x)+\mathrm{f}(2-\mathrm{x})=1+\mathrm{e}^{2} \ldots . . \text { (i) } \\
& I=\int_{0}^{2} f(x) d x=\int_{0}^{1}\{f(x)+f(2-x)\} d x=\left(1+e^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
\]

question: The value of the integral, \(\int_{1}^{3}\left[x^{2}-2 x-2\right] d x\), where \([x]\) denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\), is:
solution: NULL

question: If a curve \(y=f(x)\) passes through the point \((1,2)\) and satisfies \(x \frac{d y}{d x}+y=b x^{4}\), then for what value of \(b\), \(\int_{1}^{2} f(x) d x=\frac{62}{5}\)?
solution:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{d y}{d x}+\frac{y}{x}=b x^{3}, I . F .=e^{\int \frac{d x}{x}}=x \\
& \therefore y x=\int b x^{4} d x=\frac{b x^{5}}{5}+C
\end{aligned}
\]

Passes through \((1,2)\), we get

\(2=\frac{b}{5}+C\)

Also, \(\int_{1}^{2}\left(\frac{b x^{4}}{5}+\frac{c}{x}\right) d x=\frac{62}{5}\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{b}{25} \times 32+C \ln 2-\frac{b}{25}=\frac{62}{5} \Rightarrow C=0 \& b=10\)

question: The area (in units) of the part of the circle \(x^{2}+y^{2}=36\), which is outside the parabola \(y^{2}=9 x\), is:
\(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\int_{0}^{x^{2}}(\sin \sqrt{t}) d t}{x^{3}}\) is equal to:
solution:
\[
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\int_{0}^{x^{2}} \sin (\sqrt{t}) d t}{x^{3}}
\]

This is in \(\frac{0}{0}\) form, so use L' Hospital rule

\[
=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\frac{d}{d x}\left(\int_{0}^{x^{2}} \sin (\sqrt{t}) d t\right)}{\frac{d}{d x}\left(x^{3}\right)}
\]

\(=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\sin x \cdot 2 x-0}{3 x^{2}}\)

(applying Leibnitz rule)

\(=\frac{2}{3} \lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\sin x}{x}\)

\(=\frac{2}{3}\)
